5|# Sizing: Compared to WD My Passport Ultra 2TB Portable, Seagate is very slim. If we stack 2 Seagate Slim Plus, that much thicker is the WD My Passport Ultra 2TB Portable (NOT WD 1TB model). Compared to an iPhone 5 size, the Seagate drive is a little bit thicker (2-3mm), shorter length wise (1cm) and wider width wise (2cm). # Connectivity: This drive uses a standard blue USB 3.0 cable (included) that is backwards compatible to USB 2.0 meaning that you can plug it into any Mac or PC. And the cable is not much flexible like WD HDD. But it feels premium quality than WD. # Speed: This is result when I compared with Seagate Backup Plus Slim 2TB, WD Elements 1TB Portable (WDBPCK0010BBK-EESN) & WD My Passport Ultra 1TB Portable. (See the attached picture or use link below) http://s11.postimg.org/mvduokuir/Untitled_13.jpg # MAC Compatibility: There is a Free Paragon NTFS driver on Seagate website. You can run any NTFS storage peripherals when you install this driver. # Free bundled software: The drive includes helpful backup software and a free two-year 200GB subscription to Microsoft OneDrive online storage. # Dislikes: There are NO rubber grip pads under the HDD case. So, it is easy to slip from table/desk & doesn't reduce vibrations (HDD don't have any vibration or noise now). NO rubber pads on 4 corners inside the case of HDD. So, doesn't survive small drops. # Compared to WD: If u want 2TB HDD & exactly what the word "SLIM" means, go for Seagate. For rough use & don't care about slim size, always go for WD. All WD HDD have rubber pads on 4 corners inside the case & rubber grips under the HDD case. It will help to survive small drops & hits, reduce slip from table/desk & reduce vibrations. # WARNING: Remember, this is a electronic product. We can't predict for how many days these HDD will work. Usually, when we get these things we will use very carefully for about 2-3 months, afterwards we use roughly. If you are a rough user & always plug this on computer & share this HDD with friends, most of these won't survive very long even if they belong to the best company in portable HDD or best reviewed one. I suggest, for more secure your data, always upload your important data on one or two reputed Cloud Drives (GoogleDrive, Dropbox, iCloud). **Please use the Like button if you like this review**

4|Look and feel While the Backup Plus Slim is pretty much a basic drive in a very small enclosure, the Backup Plus Fast is actually two drives sandwiched into one body. Of course, the two are very different in terms of weight and portability. It's pretty much as small as a 2.5-inch hard drive enclosure can be, which makes us wonder how shock-resistant it actually is. My review unit had a metallic red finish on top, which was quite striking. The sides are glossy black, while the bottom is textured for a non-slip grip. Seagate includes a 0.5m USB 3.0 cable. You could easily slip this drive into a pocket and carry it around all day. Software Seagate includes both Mac and PC versions of its Dashboard utility. You have to install a registration utility as well, and you're forced to reboot before you can use any of it and then says it needs to download a 93MB update. Performance Unsurprisingly, the Backup Plus Fast outperformed its smaller sibling by a very wide margin in most tests. Both drives performed well, thanks to the fast USB 3.0 interface. You can expect sequential read and write speeds of around 106Mbps with the Slim, and 230Mbps with the Fast. Random read and write speeds, as measured by SiSoft SANDRA 2014, were more in line, with the Fast at 61.3 and 87.14Mbps as opposed to the Slim at 52.58 and 53.51 respectively. Pros Slim and light Versatile enough for everyday use Cons Slightly expensive Ratings (Out of 5) Design: 4 Performance: 3.5 Value for Money: 3.5 Overall: 3.5

5|There are plenty of reviews specifying the read and write speeds over USB 2.0 & 3.0 so no need for me to mention that again (Refer to the picture). Just a few pointers that I feel can help potential buyers. - This hard drive is the best out there in every sense (looks, performance etc.) except for the ruggedness. I will prefer Transcend or Silicon Power (SP) brand for that. Of course if it’s rugged then it will lose its sleek look. But personally for me this sleek aspect does not matter much as it is not a smartphone that I have to carry in my pockets. However I fear if this drive falls from my hand then it will be damaged. So only NON RUGGEDNESS is a con for me. BTW the metal finish looks excellent (Refer to the pictures). - I wanted Seagate BUP slim 2TB version in red color. After monitoring prices here for a few weeks I decided to go with eB*y. Got the drive there for 6699/-. At the time of writing this review it is still showing 7475/- on Amazon. But if you get similar prices then I will recommend Amazon as it is more trustworthy and easier returns. - This hard drive comes in NTFS file system format by default. The main advantage of NTFS over FAT32 is that you can store single files above 4gb and also offers better security. For more details watch this YouTube video (https://youtu.be/S5uxpHszU1E). - First thing on receiving the hard drive was to register it on ‘www.seagate.com’. Scroll down and click on REGISTER NOW. You have to enter a few of your personal details and the serial number of the drive which you can find at the back starting with S/N: - To check the warranty of your drive go to ‘www.seagate.com’ and click the following ‘Support>Warranty and returns’. A new page opens, click on ‘check my warranty’. A new page further opens, click on ‘is my drive under warranty’. On doing this step 1 expands, click on ‘check to see if your drive is under warranty”. Enter the Serial number and part number (Both mentioned on back of the drive) and submit….viola, your warranty is displayed!! - Though this drive comes with 18 inch cable as compared to 12 inch of other brands but it is still short for me as I use it with desktop or TV. So I found a nice 1Meter USB 3.0 cable here on amazon (http://www.amazon.in/gp/product/B00PZUBV6W?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01). Click on the link to read my full review on that product. Or simply type in the search on Amazon ‘USB 3.0 to micro B cable’ for other cables. - There is a thin slit at the top which hides the LED light that glows when the drive is powered on. VERDICT – The best out there. Go for it but be careful while handling. I will recommend a protective case for it though am yet to buy one myself.
5|The HDD is remarkably slim, smooth and silent without any noticeable whirring sound and is thinner than the previous versions of Backup plus HDDs. But it is more of plastic and looks easily breakable. There is a bundle of softwares "Seagate Dashboard Agent, Seagate Tools and Seagate Release.exe" provided in the HDD. This Software makes Seagate Product Registration easy. The details of Product Registration will be stored in the HDD automatically. Besides, there is Seagate Tools software and also 5GB cloud storage facility is also available. This cloud storage facility is free of charges. The writing speed when tested with 10GB Movie file reached to 102 mbps on a HP laptop and windows 8.1 platform, which is reasonable. The HDD works so silently that you have look at the streak of light on the HDD to know if it is active or not. Right now, I am using 1 TB Back up Plus (a replacement) and a 2TB WD My Passport. Besides I have 500 GB 3.5" Seagate Free Agent. The important point that makes Seagate Technology, stand apart from the rest, is their service. I give here below my experience with Seagate HDD. I purchased a 1 TB Seagate Free Agent Go Flex during April,2011 with 3 years warranty. The HDD had stopped functioning when the warranty was to expire within the next 3 months. M/S Accel Frontline, Hyderabad, the warranty service provider of Seagate HDDs, refused to entertain my warranty claim, saying that the particulars this HDD were available not in their data base. The Tax Invoice did not contain the details of the item like S/N or P/N. Then I contacted the Asian office of Seagate, located in Hong Kong, who advised me to send a few photographs of the HDD immediately. Within a few minutes after I have sent the Photographs through email, I received a call from the Head Office of M/S Accel Frontline requesting me to collect a new HDD in place of the problematic one from their Secunderabad branch office. A new Seagate Backup plus 1TB was handed over to me after a week in place of Seagate Freeagent GoFlex HDD.. The cost of the replacement for the manufacturer, may be negligible , but for a small consumer like me, the gesture is overwhelming. I can not imagine such a service with any other manufacturer. This is the reason I preferred Seagate HDD.

3|The device works fine. Connected it to a WIN XP PC. It worked when i manually copied files to it. ISSUE: But the dashboard software that auto backs up once installed did not work to auto backup data. It started coming up with a message saying INITIAL JOB PENDING. SOLUTION: The user manual did not anything to solve this issue. Then after a lot of R and D on my PC settings i found the issue. For all users who are facing this problem the solution is to right click on MY COMPUTER->MANAGE->SERVICES and then make sure the TASK SCHEDULER is enabled. The dashboard software during install or during use does not check this and enable if it in disabled and does not alert the user.

5|Seagate's Backup Plus = you may use the Seagate's backup software to automatically backup your computer data to this hard drive on schedule basis. Slim = it really is a slim ext. hard drive. Apart from being a decent, slim, backup, external HDD, there are a few other things that are worthy of mentioning about the device. It operates on your Computer's USB power with the help of a supplied, short USB 3.0 cable (backwards compatible); no other external power source needed. Despite extended periods of data transfer between a computer and the hard drive, the HDD wasn't very hot. The 3 years limited warranty by Seagate is kind of a life saver, should the device malfunction. How effective their support / service is, only the ones who contact them will know. Data transfer rates are only bottlenecked by your computer's USB port / controller. This is a USB 3.0 device, and connecting it to one such port is what gives you the best performance; whatever it is capable of. Unfortunately, I haven't run a benchmark test on it to analyze its data transfer speeds. I will update the same when I do it. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- UPDATE (20-Jan-2016) It has now been 10 months since I purchased this hard drive. A problem has arisen and the problem is that the drive does not populate in the "My Computer" window in order to access the drive. The volume does not populate in the device properties under "Device Manager" (on both, Windows XP Pro 32 bit and Windows 7 Ultimate x64). I have written about the same to Seagate support and I'm waiting for their response. I'm not sure if it is the fault of the USB port on the computer, or if it is actually the hard drive. I will update my review again in a few days to let you all know what happens. P.S. I was able to register my hard drive on Seagate's product registration site. Although it displays a different model number during the registration, it did not reject the serial number.
5|I am using this drive for almost 6-7 months and had no issues so far. I use this drive to store mass media like music, photos, videos, bulk files and backup. This way, I keep my laptop running fast by avoiding populating the internal hard drive. I am getting a average data transfer rate of about 50 to 80 Mbps on USB 3.0 and 10 to 40 Mbps on USB 2.0. I read other people's reviews that the drive often disappears from My Computer but this is not the case. If there is no activity, the drive goes in sleep mode but whenever a call is made, the drive automatically wakes up from sleep. Note: The drive won't work if you have connected it to a powerless USB hub. You will need a powered USB hub. TIP: Advice to those who want to prevent the contents of the drive from being misused. This drive is as good as a open locker. Anyone can connect the drive to their computer and copy the files. So before you start copying files, save time and install a software like USBCrypt which will create a virtual partition. That way, your drive will have a main and a virtual partition. You can decide how much space you want to allot to both the partitions. But its better to allot more space to virtual partition. The virtual partition is password protected while the content of the main partition are open to the world.
5|Excellent piece of equipment for the money you pay. I have owned multiple external hard disks, and never imagined I would take the time to review something as basic and obvious as a hard disk, since the minute differences of data transfer speeds between most of the brands really doesnt warrant the effort of typing a review. This disk however stands apart. Thin, premium, light. Its like everyone owns a car for commute but the Porsche 911 will stand out in a crowd. Going by the same simili, you will require to pay a premium for a premium product. Taking it a step further, a Honda Civic and a Porsche 911 are both cars, in everyday traffic they will take the same time in city commute from point A to B, both have the basic creature comforts but you will pay 10 times over for the Porsche. Similarly, this is a slightly faster hard drive but in daily usage the difference is not so obvious. It will store 2 TB of data, Will give you the usual seagate disk management software (which is slow, cumbersome and a pain). The form has nothing to influence the function but the lightweight, extremely thin and durable metal construction and the colored shell, all add up. If you feel thats worth the Rs 1000 odd of premium, this is the disk for you. And, there are brands offering lesser quality at a higher price. I would recommend this product.

4|Was looking for a relatively cheap hard disk drive for an eternity since my previous 2 TB external hard disk drive from Wetsern Digital crashed a year and a half from the date of purchase. Decided to go for this product because for a portable drive and the capacity that it offered, I felt it was a steal @ Rs.3,899. Also, felt safer dealing with Seagate. I've had this product for 2.5 months and so far no issues with it. Very smooth and noiseless. The biggest surprise was the size of the product. It is actually slim as it says on the product title, about as thick as a smartphone, and it is also very small, it is about the size of my wallet. As a result it easily fits into any pocket and is portable in the true sense of the word. For the capacity that it offers, I think the size of the product is a big big plus. On the flip side, what you see is NOT what you get. Namely, although it says 1 TB on the product, the physical storage space is only 931 GB. Now, up to a certain extent I am ok with the lesser space, but a total loss of 69 GB was I feel a bit much. Something in the region of 30-40 GB would have been fine. Also, while multitasking, like creating a new folder on the hard disk during the course of a data transfer the disk hangs for 3-5 seconds which is kind of off-putting. Other than this, nothing much to complain about as yet.

5|The hard drive inside is ST4000LM016, featuring 2.5 inch, 15 mm, standard SATA port. The logical sector size is 512 bytes. This is important since the maximum LBA of this hard drive is 4 TB / 512 B, which is significantly greater than 2^32 - 1. If another 4 TB hard drive offers 4K logical sector size, then the maximum LBA will be 4 TB / 4096 B, which does not exceed 2^32 - 1. However, as of today, there is no consumer hard drive except Intel SSD 750 series, that offers 4K logical sector size. Xbox One internal hard drive mounting point does support standard 2.5 inch SATA hard drives up to 15 mm perfectly, but unfortunately current version of Xbox One UEFI does not support booting from partitions which LBA is greater than 2^32 - 1. Still, you can use it as a Xbox One internal hard drive but the maximum capacity supported is (2 ^ 32 - 1) * 512 bytes. This is just a little bit larger than 2TB drives. Therefore, it is pointless to replace Xbox One internal hard drive with this one, unless Microsoft updates UEFI to fix this 2^32 - 1 limit in future versions. Needless to say, using this as a Xbox One external hard drive, you can get the full capacity.

I went on to look for a way to get more space and found this external hard drive. After looking at Youtube on how to expand the PS4 storage, I discover that you can buy this external hard drive and take off the cover and find a hard drive that can replace the drive for the PS4 500 gb. So I decided to buy this portable external hard drive and open the hard drive up (which voids the warranty). When you use the hard drive to the computer, it would have a light that indicate that it's on. I switch the hard drive that is 500 gb to the cover of the 2tb drive. I screw on the 2tb drive to the ps4 and have to wait for the PS4 to reformat. Before switching the hard drive, I would highly recommend to back up the game save files online or onto a flash drive. After switching the hard drive, I would have to turn on the PS4 and do a clean install for the PS4. I have to put game disc in the PS4 in order to be able to play the games and update the games as well. I also downloaded the game save files to the PS4 onto the hard drive. After removing the 2tb hard drive from the case that holds the 2tb drive, there is a tin foil around it. I ripped up the tin foil and threw it away. I should've put the tin foil to the 500gb to be able to use the 500 gb portable hard drive. I tried to connect the 500 gb portable hard drive to my laptop, but nothing happens. So I made a mistake there, but I'm not sure whether if you put the tin foil onto the 500 gb drive that it can work as another external hard drive. So I highly suggest that you should put the tin foil and not rip it. The tin foil should be attached to the 500 gb in order for the external hard drive to work, but I'm not sure since I haven't tried that yet. All in all, I was happy to upgrade my PS4 storage, but I can't really use the 500 gb external hard drive anymore becoming a brick instead.

5|I bought this drive and a Sata Male to Female Data and Power Combo Extension Cable ( http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00L9R3AKA ) for use in my PS4. With firmware update 3.15 released by Sony, sleep mode now works with 4TB drives. I connect the extension cable to the hard drive connections inside the PS4, then run the cable out to this external hard drive enclosure. I cut a rectangle slot using a dremel so the cable plugs into the hard drive directly. You can't fit this drive in the PS4 hard drive cage due to it being too thick, however by running the extension cable you can get 8 times the storage capacity (upgrading from 500GB PS4) for about $125. No downsides now thanks to Sony's 3.15 update! Be sure to back up your game saves online or to a USB drive before you install the drive. Download the latest update file from the PlayStation website: https://www.playstation.com/en-us/support/system-updates/ps4/#newinstallation Put it on your flash drive in this structure: D:\PS4\UPDATE\PS4UPDATE.PUP (where D: is your flash drive's drive letter) Then plug the flash drive into PS4 with it powered off, plug your USB cord into your DualShock 4 controller. Power the system into safe mode by pressing and holding for 7+ seconds until you hear the second beep. Choose option 7, choose YES to reinitiliaze. It will copy the file off the flash drive onto the hard drive, reboot the PS4, then ask you to proceed with the installation.

My specific usage case scenario and intended application is to copy and paste tons of random data of various file names and sizes between my desktop and laptop. I also pay for CrashPlan+ Family Plan to backup my private user data to CrashPlan Central off-site from my apartment. In this regard, this product appealed to me for its ultra high capacity more so than its performance or the current offering of up to 200 GB of Microsoft OneDrive storage for a limited period of time (I have not taken advantage of this offer yet because I pay for Microsoft Office 365 Home and I receive up to 1 TB with my paid subscription). Where things get more interesting is my other more narrow usage case scenarios for specific applications. I purchased VMWare Workstation 12 Pro 64 bit for GNU/Linux and I also paid for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, Microsoft Windows 10 Pro, and Apple Macintosh OS X 10.11 El Capitan 64 bit. Installing these guest virtual machines and running them on my Seagate Backup Plus FAST are incredible because they are so freakishly fast. I own a Western Digital Black 3.5" SATA-III 6 GB/s 6.0 TB 7,200 RPM 128 MB cache desktop hard disk drive and I swear that my Seagate Backup Plus FAST is as fast as my WD Black desktop hard disk drive albeit at a lower capacity and price than I paid for it. Another example would be my large SteamOS + GNU/Linux PC game library. I downloaded, installed, and play various PC games off of my Seagate Backup Plus FAST and it is nearly as fast as my WD Black or my Crucial M550 2.5" 7.00 mm SATA-III 6 GB/s 1 TB solid state disk. Of course, game loading performance does not dramatically improve by upgrading to a high capacity SATA-III 6 GB/s SSD over a standard mechanical hard disk drive in my experience. However, this Seagate Backup Plus FAST loads the most popular AAA SteamOS + GNU/Linux PC games extremely fast nevertheless while providing a few terabytes of available disk space left over for more data. The key selling point is your own usage case scenario and specific workload or intended applications for this Seagate Backup Plus FAST product. For me, I chose the ultra high 4.0 TB capacity over performance and it meets my needs adequately. I would not rely on this product as it is configured in RAID-0 with no data protection features as a backup drive. It can be used as an ultra high capacity, high performance, and portable scratch disk for IT professionals and creative professionals alike while traveling worldwide. This would be a good usage case scenario for such folks considering this product to add to their tech carry on bags. If you are considering this product, then I do strongly recommend that you consider exactly how you would use it for. The performance is there and it is the highest capacity portable hard disk drive currently on the market at the time of this writing. This is the best portable hard disk drive I have owned yet.

5|Okay, so I bought this 4tb drive to upgrade my new TiVo Bolt. Disassembling the drive was straight forward. The enclosure is a plastic tub with a metal top. Once you have a corner lifted, it comes apart fairly easily. There is metalized tape around the top of the drive which peels loose. Then the drive will lift out. I have used many hard drives, from 5MB to recent 5TB models from a dozen manufacturers. Over the years, several of these drives have failed. My usual procedure is to destroy the drive or just store it until the information is no longer relevant. Recently, I retired 5 drives which were 5 to 8 years old, but still working. I was forced to return the drive with the data intact for replacement. The replacement drive failed within 2 weeks and I returned it also. Now, to keep my data from being compromised if the drive should fail, I use whole drive encryption. While a little inconvenient, it gives me peace of mind to know that my data cannot be retrieved should I have to return the drive under warranty. I also am using a dual backup system for my laptop, with two USB 3.0 1TB hard drives in rotation. These two drives are from different manufacturers, to spread the risk of single drive failures. Periodically, I copy the contents of these portable drives to my main 5TB backup and various other drives, including a NAS server. I have no desire to put all of my data in the cloud, because of security concerns. I insist on keeping physical control of my data, which is why I have adopted these practices. With the cost per terabyte of storage in the $50 range, this system is not expensive for my needs.

Reformats (and HDDs) can be questionable, so I started with one movie and two T.V. shows (10 seasons on the first show, seven seasons on the second). After the transfer finished, I correctly ejected the drive, waited a few seconds, and reinserted. (Note: my Mac takes *forever* to recognize this drive. WD's and Lacie's show up on my desktop within 10 seconds, but the 4TB Seagate averages between 1-2 minutes. Not really sure why). Opened the drive and saw the folders for the movie and the two T.V. shows. I decided to play it safe, so I opened the T.V. show with seven seasons and found Seasons 3 and 4 were gone. I started checking all of the folders and found in addition to Seasons 3 and 4 being gone, several individual episodes from the remaining seasons had been corrupted or were missing. Closed the folder, properly ejected the drive again, waited, and reinserted. Opened the drive, folders were still there, but the missing and corrupted files were still ... missing and corrupted. I decided to look at the other T.V. show. That one had all 10 seasons in it, and looked normal. I figured at this point, I'd better check the movie, too. Folder was still there, but when I opened it, the movie file was missing. I concluded that maybe the transfer faced some sort of technical hiccup, so I deleted all of the files from the 4TB drive, and re-transferred them. Same story happened all over again, except this time, the movie was fine, but I lost episodes/seasons from both T.V. shows. Disgruntled, I took the time to upload individual episode files (all of the missing and corrupted ones) to the drive, one by one. Finished that, properly ejected the drive, and waited. Reinserted and everything seemed to stick this time. No missing files, no corrupted files. All seemed well. Been slowly adding more of my library to the drive over the past few days, and so far no issues. Everything is there, everything plays. Not sure what the deal was with the first two rounds. Maybe the drive just needed to be broken in? Or adjust to the newly installed driver on it? Who knows... Overall, a sketchy drive for Mac users... My advice would be to do something similar to my method *before* you put anything of great importance on this drive. Here's to hoping my files stick. So far, 2-star rating just because it was annoying having to transfer the same files multiple times to make sure they were secure. Will update in the future if I run into any more problems or if I feel the drive is stable enough to earn a higher rating. Probably stick with WD's and Lacie's in the future, though...

4|i've bought seagate expansion hoping that it would support 4k logical.. man.. i was so wrong. one would think "backup" plus means backward compatibility, for those who knows about ppl encountering backup issues due to 4k logical sector, so seagate expansion would be 4k logical. nope, that isn't the case here. the price difference is not justifiable as well. inside the backup plus enclosure is a Samsung branded hdd whereas in seagate expansion, it's a seagate branded hdd. the cushioning of the hdd is better in backup plus. it's smaller too. cheaper too! for those looking for a low-powered high capacity portable hdd with 4k logical sector, you will be disappointed. the single hdd in the enclosure even though stated as AF, advanced format, translates 4k physical sector into 512b logical. what this means is without an interface to retranslate back to 4k sector, you will never be able to have full compatibility with legacy device which has a limit of 32bit addressing. you will never be able to address the full capacity in MBR. you cannot format it as MBR Fat32 partition, only GPT Fat32 or NTFS or other partitioning system. you will fall back to a 2tb "max" hdd. the only solution now is to disassemble the unit, get a 4k interface which could translate 512b back to 4k logical sector and interface with the hdd. seagate freeagent goflex interface seems to be the only option as far as i know.

It is not frozen, it is doing its thing. . Takes about three to four minutes to format. The speeds are as expected being USB 3.0. For PS4 hard drive, upgrade keep reading: The drive is 113.5mm long and 76mm wide. The thickness is what you need to worry yourself with if installing in a PS4. This drive is the proper thickness. Other brands are too thick. Removal Instructions (Warranty will be void): - Watch this video on Youtube and you should be able to easily remove the cover off you drive without damaging it beyond use. Note: I used a blade for prying the top and bottom of the case apart. https://youtu.be/qo8-F9kzlIw For PS4 setup you will need to back up your PS$ hard drive to a dedicated external hard drive (all data will be lost). Then install this drive in the PS4. Initialize the new hard drive in the PS4 using a download of the latest PS4 firmware off Sony’s website to either the external HD or a USB thumb drive. Lastly restore the backup from the external hard drive. Optional: install the PS4 hard drive in the enclosure if you were able to salvage it.

5|Works as you'd expect from a hard drive and it doesn't require an additional power source other than USB. That's all I can ask for. I have this connected to a 3rd-generation AirPort Extreme via USB to serve as a Time Machine backup drive for multiple computers. A lot of people seem to think this is only possible with a 6th-generation AirPort Extreme, but it works with 3rd-gen and above, as far as I can see. Apple's documentation seems to be incorrect in this regard. Here are the steps to do so (as best as I remember): 1. Connect the drive to your computer directly 2. Format it in Disk Utility as Mac OS Extended, journaled, non-encrypted. (The encryption process comes later, if you want to do it.) 3. Add a partition for every computer you'd like to back up. Make sure they're all Mac OS Extended, journaled and NON-ENCRYPTED! 4. Eject the drive. 5. Connect the drive to the AirPort Extreme. 6. In the Finder (on the computer you wish to backup), locate your AirPort Extreme and double click the partition you want to use as a backup. 7. Navigate to the Time Machine preferences in System Preferences, and set up Time Machine with the partition you connected to in the Finder. This is where you can choose to use encryption, but you can only do so if your computer's internal hard drive is already encrypted (you can set this up in System Preferences > Security and Privacy > FileVault). This works amazingly well. My Macs connect to the Backup Plus regularly to do hourly backups over the network, automatically. When the Backup Plus isn't connected to, it goes to sleep. It wakes up with no problems at all when a computer needs to do a backup. I take my Macbook to school with me and when I get home and connect to the Wi-Fi network, the backups automatically begin immediately. It truly just works the way I want it to.

5|Great drive for backups and very easy software to use. A great buy at the price.
3|Update: After having the drive for a few weeks, I'm giving up and returning it. Out of 12 PCs I work with regularly, only 2 consistently worked well with this drive. 10 of them would fail to read or transfers would fail often that making using this drive became a risk/unreliable. Possibly a lemon Original review: This drive is amazing - 4tb in about the space of my previous 1tb external drive, as well as being inexpensive for what you're getting. The price dropped 10.00 two days after I bought it, too, har har Amazon The only issue I had was starting computers up with the drive plugged in. There is a little bit about this issue if you Google, but nothing that really helped me. Here is an outline of what I discovered, I hope this helps. When I first got the drive, I immediately formatted it to exFat, since I intended it to be used with both PCs and Macs. The reasons for and against doing this: - PRO: exFat lets you read/write on both without doing anything special (OS X won't write to NTFS drives without 3rd party intervention) - CON: Windows's built in Backup and Restore won't backup a system image to exFat without some tricks I found I couldn't boot two of my PCs while the drive was plugged in, except randomly on one of them (see below). On one, the PC stops at the BIOS splash screen before even getting to the point where you can press keys to get into the BIOS. After letting it sit for an hour, I had to power it down (keyboard unresponsive, so no ctrl+alt+del). Without the drive plugged in, the computer boots as normal. Once into Windows, I could plug in the drive and use it fine. On the other PC, it does one of two things randomly: It will let you get into the BIOS, but won't detect any other drives (internal or external) after this point, so won't boot; or it will detect other drives and boot, but all other USB devices (keyboard, mouse, wifi adapter) will be disabled while the drive is plugged in. Once Windows was up, if I unplugged the drive, my other USB devices came back. This was with the various USB devices plugged into ports all around my PC - wifi in the front, keyboard/mouse dongle in a USB 2 port on the back, the Seagate in its own USB 3 port on the back, etc. Suspecting some kind of power draw issue, I tried plugging the drive into a separate, powered USB 3 hub, with no effect. After some searching, I examined my UEFI settings in the BIOSes of both machines, but they were already set as the forum posts I found suggested. "Solution" (found by accident): After giving up, I intended to return it to Amazon. I had put some data on it, so I plugged it back into one PC and proceeded to do a full (not quick) format, using NTFS. Some time after this completed, I needed to restart the computer for something else, and rebooted it, forgetting the Seagate was still plugged in. It booted fine. Wondering what was going on, I tried it in the other PC as well, and this one also booted. I quick formatted back to exFat, and both PCs reacted as before - without booting or acting crazy. Quick formatted back to NTFS, and no issue. >>> I don't have any explanation for the above behavior, but that is the symptom and what resolved it. <<< For me, this isn't much of a resolution, since I really wanted to use exFat on it given the drive will be floating around between platforms. I'm still on the fence about whether to return it, but I left 4 stars since it mostly does what it is supposed to, has a ton of space, and a good price.

5|These are wonderful in that these are reliable back-up storage EHDs that are metal encased. Furthermore, these are very reasonably priced and relatively large capacity drives.
4|I purchased the 4TB Fast version and my feedback is specific to this unit only and may not apply to other versions. I bought this to expand the storage on my Xbox One, but in comparison to other External HDDs there are a few things unique about this particular model you should know about. As other reviews have mentioned, this uses two 2TB Hard Drives in a RAID 0 setup which is pretty unique for an external HDD. For non-techies what this means is that it splits the data between the two drives. A benefit is that you have potential to double the typical read/write speeds since you have two drives accessing the same amount of data. Real world results will vary, but this is how Seagate can advertise the product as being 'Fast' relative to their other offerings. Also since data is split across two drives, you get double the storage capacity compared to other single drive external HDDs. This comes with one major downside. If one of the two drives fail, all of the data will be unusable and with two drives you increase your chance of failure. Don't be alarmed, just know there are trade offs to this design before you purchase. High risk, high reward. Also since there are two drives you will need more power than your typical portable external HDD. Seagate knew this and gives you two USB cables. Both connect will connect to the Seagate unit but the cables have either one or two USB connectors. The reason is that if your device has limited power output through its USB ports, you can use the cable with two USB connectors to give it some extra power, this is a 'Y' cable. On the Y cable with two connectors, one has a blue plastic to mark it as the USB 3.0 data connector. The other USB connector is completely black and is used for the supplying the additional power. The standard cable with just one connector is USB 3.0 and data. It is straight forward and like any other data cable. Since this uses two disks, it needs more power and I recommend using the Y connector when possible. I first tried using the single USB 3.0 cable on my Xbox One. My Xbox One detected it, formatted it, and it looked like it was working. However, when you do anything that really utilizes the HDD, the Xbox became very unstable with very slow transfer speeds. It would fail to load games despite it showing up as fully detected by the Xbox. Games would transfer from the internal to the external drive, but it was very slow. I spent most of an evening trying to troubleshoot it, thinking the drive could be defective. I went ahead and tried the Y connector and fixed all problems. If you have instability issues or slow transfers try the Y cable, it could just be a power issue. One tip I can provide is that if you need to use the Y cable for the additional power and you have a limited number of USB ports on your device, plug the blue USB 3.0 connector into your primary device and you can plug the black USB power connector into any other secondary device that is powered. That 2nd power connector is only needed for power, so it doesn't have to connect to the primary device. I did this on my Xbox One since it has 3 USB ports and I didn't want to dedicate two of them to this external HDD. I plugged the blue USB 3.0 data connector into the Xbox one and I plugged the black power USB connector into a nearby secondary device (cable box) that had a open USB port I knew I wasn't going to use. This setup works perfectly and lets me use the other USB ports on the Xbox for the controller charging cable and other accessories.

5|I have owned one of these 2 TB drives for over one year and am very pleased with its operation. It is extremely quiet, includes a top indicator light which is lit when drive is mounted via USB, and works well with either USB 2 or USB3. Although the drive is 5400 RPM (as are all bus-powered "portable" drives I have seen), its USB-3 performance is nearly as good as 7800 models, due to Windows inefficiencies. As with all bus-powered drives, use a "Y" cable with USB-2 connections unless the host computer/host or hub routinely provides double the 500 mA USB-2 spec (which many do). I have recently purchased three more of these. With extended usage (20 minutes or more continuous reading or writing), the drive gets quite warm, but not so hot it cannot be held. Cooling is radiant only (no fan). My primary use is for backing up 20,000 to 50,000 files at a time which exercises the drive very heavily for 20 to 30 minutes.

While I guess that isn't the most ridiculous policy, it seems not very customer-friendly (i.e. not respectful, nor appreciative). A PORTABLE drive that breaks that easily should NOT be considered portable. While the price here is favorable, I highly recommend spending a little bit more for a SOLID STATE drive if you want something that is actually portable and you can feel safe carrying it around with you. UPDATE: The girl I am working with informed me that the drive that slipped and stopped working was a replacement (via warranty) for another drive she had before. Because this drive is a replacement, it is under the original warranty which has expired (it does not receive its own warranty). I do not know the circumstances of why the original drive failed, but the fact that the replacement didn't last long is a indication that you should NOT purchase this hard drive (especially if you want to carry it around with you). I seems several people are experiencing the same problem with their Seagate USB drives, why not share the solution with all? I'm running Win 7Pro 64 Bit. Please help. Thanks. mdb ************************************************************** Update 9/25/2015 ************************************************************************ I read about others having difficulty with Seagate Tech Support and getting a drive returned so I thought I would avoid this by filing a claim with the Square Trade extended warranty. Square Trade will not honor their warranty until after manufacturer's warranty is expired. They will however reimburse shipping expenses to return to manufacturer. So I called Seagate and talked with a very helpful gentleman in Tech Support who help me troubleshoot the drive problem and then took my information to return the drive under warranty. I had several shipping options ranging from returning via USPS and UPS at ground, 2nd day, or overnight cost ranging from about $10 to $27. I opted of 2nd day at $14. When I receive the new drive in a few days, I package the old drive in the same packaging and return with prepaid shipping label included with new drive. This process was much easier than described by others. I will update if there are any problems, but not if everything goes well as I expect it will.

5|All I wanted was a large memory external drive that would behave like a thumbdrive which allow me to easily add, remove, and transfer files between different computers. I was extremely disappointed and about to give this a One Star rating when I first tried to use this device. I have several PCs and just one Mac that is used by my daughter. Before she left for college, she asked me if I could back up her files. While all my external drives were recognized on the Mac, we could not add any files from the Mac, could not delete anything from the drives, nor find any fixes to change this. They were read only. She could only copy files from my drives into her Mac, but not the other was around. All I found on the web were suggestions to reformat my drives to be avoid the NTFS format used by PCs. That was unacceptable. So I bought this device after challenging various sales people at stores first to verify that this would work in all my machines. The box even says "easy backup for PC, Mac, and mobile devices". But what it didn't say, and what I learned, is that you cannot freely move files in and out between different machine types right out of the box, especially Macs. I wasted all morning trying to find a solve and was about to package this up to return it and give it the lowest rating possible. But I found a solution. First, I went ahead and used the Time Machine utility to set up the drive. This is the only way I could find to reformat it into the state it needed to get to in order to transfer files from my Mac. So that problem was solved. The new problem is that by doing so, none of my PCs recognized it any longer. I took a chance by going into the Seagate support site and downloading something called Paragon Drive for Windows. As of this date, you'll find it at http://www.seagate.com/support/external-hard-drives/desktop-hard-drives/backup-plus-desk-mac/ According to the description, this driver provides read and write access for Seagate “for Mac” drives in Windows without having to reformat. The thing to remember is that your drive has to be connected when you download and install. And there is a mandatory reboot of your PC. Voila! The drive was recognized and I am now able to freely move files into and out of the drive from any of my machines, even Mac. I like it much more now. And with 2TB in a device the size of a wallet, it's very convenient. No external power cord needed. The included USB cable is all it takes. Hope this saves someone a ton of grief if trying to share this between PCs and Macs.

1|The Seagate Backup Plus Slim 1TB Portable External Hard Drive is conceptionally and aesthetically a very attractive and potentially useful device. The affordable price makes it a bargain, but also underscores how it’s not a priority for Seagate to provide proper maintenance for this product, namely updated drivers and software. Despite being listed as compatible with Windows 10, the drive isn’t recognized by the operating system on some computers, namely desktops that originally shipped with Windows 7, and error messages abound due to “driver errors.” The date of the driver that automatically loaded is 2006 so it’s clearly outmoded. Plug and play should be rudimentary by now and Seagate isn’t properly supporting their wares. Microsoft claims this drive is compatible with Windows 10, but it’s not for many of us. Seagate technical support admitted that many people now using Windows 10 are having difficulties and are studying the situation, but so far no new drivers have been made available. Until someone steps up, this is a brick with a USB cord attached.

1|I purchased four of these drives for use on a Mac Pro. All four suffer from intermittent data corruption problems. I have spent a week isolating the problem to these drives. I have recreated the problem on OS X Mavericks and Yosemite, on three different model Macs, on different USB cables, on different USB ports and hubs. The problem moves with the drives. I believe there is clearly a design defect in these drives. The symptom is occasional corruption of directory or other drive structure data when used for large high speed transfers (i.e. copy of 800GB). It does not occur always, but often enough that a drive will end up corrupted within a week of usage. To try to recover I use OS X disk utility to reformat the drive (with loss of all data). A new corruption will then occur again. This is the most insidious form of defect. It is possible to lose or corrupt data and not know it until later. When it occurs it is not clear whether it is due to software, the computer hardware, cables, or the drive. It took dozens of hours to isolate it to the drives.

5|My "Seagate 2TB Slim Red", as I renamed it, came a day early well packaged & pretty in red. Its 18" USB 3.0 cable fits tightly on both ends. This Dell Inspiron i5 3542, Win 8.1, immediately put a "Safely Remove..." icon on the Taskbar & chirped. I DO use that icon when I want to disconnect it, although I see, in Device Manager, Windows set it for "quick removal". And I leave it set that way. (Aready I've rebooted & let the laptop sleep forgetting to use that icon with no detectable ill effects - but no writing was going on that I know of.) Quick Removal: Disables write caching, but supposedly no need to use icon. Better Performance: Enables write caching, but must use the icon. (Dell Diagnostics says... Cache Size: >= 32.0 MB.) I ran Dell's performance tests: smart status, 2 smart thresholds tests, targeted read, random seek, funnel seek, 2 linear read tests - & it passed each. The optional SMART Extended Self Test ran for 6+ hours, & it passed. I'm extremely pleased the drive got only midling warm (it has no vent holes) & never clinked or clanked the whole time. I could only hear it spinning by getting close. And I lifted & tilted & held it an hour+ during the tests, but never turned it upside down. (Now/then I felt a tiny kick in there; hence, the cesarians some here have performed on theirs. But I'll let mine come to term on its own!) Left plugged in for 10+ hours today - but little/no activity - it isn't even midling warm, though the 2.5" disk is spinning. Pursuant to my main reason for getting the drive, I did a MS System Image Backup. It offered to backup the EFI System partition, C:, & WINRETOOLS to "Seagate 2TB Slim Red" & took just a tad over 7 minutes to do it. I see the WindowsImageBackup folder that was created is 28.5 GB huge & the drive's used space increased accordingly. I did reboot to System Image Recovery & was pleased to see the 2TB Slim listed as a recovery drive with the image shown by date for selection. So, I must say I'm very pleased through four days of ownership. Definitely, I will update this review should anything go wrong. But I fully expect I'm invincible now... (1) Dell recovery image partition (to factory install) (2) MS Recovery USB Flash drive (Control Panel\All Control Panel Items\Recovery - Create a recovery drive) This is necessary to boot without engaging partitions you intend to overwrite with the Current System Image during a restore. This also has a copy of my Dell factory image for refresh/reset purposes. (3) Current System Image on my Seagate 2TB Slim Red (Control Panel\System and Security\File History - System Image Backup) So, I'm all signed up to get the Win 10 upgrade! - UPDATE 8/8/15: All continues to work well with my Seagate 2TB Slim RED. In addition to two for Win 8.1, it now holds two full system backups for Win 10. Back in July, I gave it a brother: Seagate 2TB Slim Blue. It too worked well out of the box, w/o installing the Seagate software. I put a clone of Win 8.1 onto it, before taking the upgrade to Win 10. Before that, I did run... PS C:\Windows\system32> chkdsk E: /R The type of the file system is NTFS. Volume label is Seagate 2TB Slim Blue. Stage 1: Examining basic file system structure ... 256 file records processed. 5|I had no problems connecting it to my old Windows 7 computer. I loaded all of the pictures, documents and programs that I wanted on to the drive, it loaded relatively quickly considering it was a few hundred GB. I unplugged it and replugged it, all the information is still there, hallelujah.
3|After my last Seagate external hard drive gave up the ghost (entirely my fault for dropping it), I decided to purchase a replacement -- I had no desire to lose all my pictures, documents, and music due to a hardware failure. This particular hard drive isn't too dissimilar from my old one -- same size, same brand, only a bit of a different shape -- and I found it suits my needs just fine. It has plenty of room for backing up my most important files, and even allows for some extra storage space in case I need it. And it's pretty easy to use -- even someone with only a basic knowledge of how to use a computer can use it. But there's one factor that keeps me from giving this a four-or-five-star review, and unfortunately it's a big one -- the accompanying software. Like many users, I installed this hard drive's accompanying Seagate Dashboard program to my computer and used it to back up my documents. And immediately I ran into problems. Seagate Dashboard eats up a LOT of CPU usage, and my computer would slow to a crawl even when the Dashboard wasn't running a backup. Programs would lock up for minutes at a time -- and any computer user can tell you that minutes feel like hours when it comes to computer usage. After trying many other solutions, I finally concluded that the slowdowns and lockups began occurring AFTER I purchased the hard drive, and I uninstalled Dashboard, which set things right again. I still recommend this drive, or really any external hard drive -- having a backup of your most valuable data is a must for any computer user. But I recommend against installing Seagate Dashboard. It's an unnecessary program, and you can easily back up your files using Windows Backup, or simply dragging and dropping files.

4|I decided to get this as opposed to the nearest competition due to an article I read touting the performance, and I am not disappointed. I intended the unit to be used as a cheap and quick general network back-up. I know it is intended as a portable back-up, but for the price, I thought it would do fine for what I needed. It is connected to an HP DL380 server running ESXI 5.5, and have it connected through an added USB 3.0 card dedicated to a windows 7 VM. Initially I had some very disappointing performance where it is very slow connected to the native DL380 USB 2.0 ports, but with addition of the USB 3.0 port, it is faster than the 7200 rpm WD Blue on a desktop system. I ran disk performance tests with Chrystal Disk Bench and ATTO and got consistently 130MB/s transfer on large files. This is great for backing up large volumes of files over the LAN. Interestingly, Both Chrystal Disk Bench and ATTO show write speeds exceeding the read. I gave it a 4 stars instead of five because i think it needs a disk activity light. The light on the case only seems to indicate that power is applied. Note: to get the full speed, you must limit the USB 3.0 cable to the length of the one (SATA/USB) included. Anything longer and the performance starts to degrade pretty significantly.

5|This is a fantastic drive. I am a major hardware geek, especially when it comes to drives (desktop, mobile, SSD, whatever). Your life and work (or school) are stored on drives, so I keep many around, usually in pairs -- one of which I keep in a fire safe at all times. I also have this drive in the larger (thicker) dual-platter size, and I don't like it nearly as much. Although the price difference is small between the 500GB and 1TB drives, I like the 500GB better. It is plenty big for OS and files -- about anything other than video. The 500GB drive is just super slim and SUPER quiet. It is about 9mm versus the 12mm listed on this page. I am burned-out on loud drives, and this sleek, thin drive is not only quiet but well-built and handsome. I got this as part of the VINE program, but I subsequently purchased a twin silver one in 500GB. I then purchased the 1TB (thicker), but I don't like the 1TB drive nearly as much. It is thicker and louder. The tops of these are real metal with a nice machined logo on them. The sides are shiny plastic which I don't like as much because it scratches easy and shows fingerprints. The bottom is a nice, matte, textured black plastic. The LEDs are white and in a slit which has a nice effect. The slimmer 500GB also minimizes the black sides while emphasizing the nice top. I have not had any problems with any of these. I was tempted to buy some of the 2TB drives, which are a fantastic price, but they are even louder, and you basically destroy the nice case if you try to extract them. In fact, the 2TB drives are louder than my WD Green desktop drives. So, despite the price, the 500GB is really my pick of the litter. They also make a Mac version in silver which, instead of a brushed silver finish, comes in a matte silver finish.

5|I love this external drive! I have been using it on my 2013 retina macbook pro, and have not had any issues. I have windows 8 on my laptop through bootcamp, so I found the need to partition the drive. I used "disk utility" (the native mac program) to partition the drive into 3 sections. I split it into: - a 400 GB Mac OS Extended (Journaled) to be used for osx time machine backups - a 200 GB NTFS partition to be used for windows backups - the rest was a 1.4 TB ExFAT partition which I used for common file storage, which can be accessed by a mac or windows os. This has worked out great for me, and have had no issues with the disk formats. ExFAT works seamlessly between the two operating systems, and the backups work great too. I have never used the Seagate software, and there is really no need to in my eyes. The native backup programs do their job well, and I don't know what more you could need.

I contacted Seagate customer support, and they were helpful and responsive, but even trying their suggestions (most of which I had done previously on my own), but the issue is not resolved. They suggested I return the disk for a different product (the Backup Plus for Mac). Their recommendation was "To determine if the drive is the issue or the USB 3.0 ports are causing the slow transfer, I recommend connecting the drive to a USB 2.0 port on the computer if you have one. Try running the Time Machine backup again and see if it is going faster than the USB 3.0 transfer. If it is, the drive is causing the issue and I recommend exchanging it for the Backup Plus for Mac drive. The chipsets are different from the PC version and Mac version and this can affect the transfer rate. I would refer you to the point of sale for the exchange. Be sure to get the drive that says "For Mac" not "For Mac and PC". I only have USB 3.0 on my Mac (running 10.10.3, and I have a 2TB disk with about 300 Gb used). In theory, USB 3.0 is 5 Gbps, but I would assume that is a burst speed. Having said that, I would think the Time Machine backup would complete within 24 hours. Prior to that backup, I did a straight copy of all my files, and the straight copy did complete overnight. My "policy" now - if I can't afford the insurance on a drive, I can't afford a drive.
5|Love it
5|Excellent product!
5|I purchased this for my PS4 so I can't speak for anything other than that. I have been burned by Seagate HDs more than a few times in the past so I was at first a little reluctant to go forward with this purchase. But after reading the reviews and comparing my options for upgrading my PS4 system storage to something more substantial, I bit the bullet because this drive seemed like good value for my money. I was originally going to get the Seagate 2TB standalone drive but someone posted that the drive in this was the same thing for less money but more steps. I like saving money as much as the next guy so I went with the more steps option. The drive fits perfectly inside the system once you remove it from the original case. It was easy to remove and do the swap. Just be careful when removing the USB adapter plug and realize that your warranty is null and void once you open the case. I just used a small flat edge screwdriver to get it started and pulled it off the rest of the way with my fingers. I actually reversed the process with the original 500GB HD from the PS4 and put that one into the Seagate case, so now I still have a spare 500GB external drive laying around. I just formatted it and it works great. Make sure you backup everything on your PS4 before you do the switch because it will wipe everything when you replace the HD. I have two profiles on my system but only one is PS Plus(auto cloud backup availability). I just assumed that everything would be backed up universally on my system since I had the Plus service, but the non-plus profile stuff was not backed up online. So have a flash drive or something to backup your stuff before you remove the original HD. Steps to get your PS4 up and running can be found on the Playstation web site (google PS4 HD upgrade) but it can be summed up into the following: 1. Backup your data to the cloud or flash drive 2. Swap drives 3. Download new (current) PS4 full system file from Sony website and copy to flash drive per the instructions on their site 4. Plug in the flash drive with the software on it to the PS4, power on the PS4, hold power for 7 secs until system beeps a second time(safe mode) 5. Choose to Initialize PS4 (Reinstall System Software) 6. Choose your USB drive or disc if using a disc and let the system update and activate 7. Download your digital games from the PS Network/Restore your backups from the cloud or flash drive 8. Enjoy your spacious new HD!

Now my photos are safely backed up and all is well unless my house burns down. When I plug the USB connector into the computer from the drives, they power up and show in Windows Explorer. I actually do not use Windows Explorer. I use PowerDesk 9 for backups and it works great. It has a mode called Sync, and I point it to the drive with all of my photos (C: drive) and to the same folder with my photos on the Seagate Drive, and click on Sync. It synchronizes both folders and that is all I have to do to backup all my new pictures. It works for me and may not work for you.

5|I've been a computer tech off and on for 33 years, and initially when I bought this drive I was taken aback by how poorly functioning it was. The fact that I purchased it brand new, use it on a modern system, and with today's drive technology available to Seagate, I just assumed it would be the best of the best for a portable "pocket" drive. Right? Well, it is. It's blazingly fast, remarkable considering it's a USB powered slower RPM pocket drive, with flawless transfer rates and error free performance. Awesome! More than I hoped for! So what was the issue? Well, initially I needed the drive to work easily between my Mac and PC, software free, so I formatted it according to the old FAT 32 system for DOS, which both platforms read. Worked perfectly fine on the Mac, but with my PC it performed like a one-legged dog back from an all-nighter at the bar after 2 hours of sleep. Not suspecting the format/driver issue at first, I left a bad review here BUT - Seagate responded promptly and invited me to call in for help. Wow! Tech support answered quickly (I could end my review right there, that in itself is amazing) and the first thing I mentioned was the format, and my new suspicion that maybe that could be the issue. The tech agreed, we reformatted it to NTFS and it's been great every since. Probably the best performing drive I own, utterly silent, smaller than most phones these days, and solidly built. (Nice looking, too). Thankfully I don't need the drive for my Mac any longer, but for Mac or multi-platform users just be aware of this issue. It worked, but the transfer rate was a literal crawl when transferring files on the PC with the FAT-32 formatting. Hope this helps.

Western Digital's Ultra Metal model comes close, and may be about the same, but I played with both, and I think the build quality on this guy feels a bit better. I like everything about this except the cable--I never like the cable for external portable drives. The cable for an external hard drive is nearly as important as the drive itself. I wanted something that could connect and be wound to the side (without being damaged over time). I don't want a cable that has to be wound up separately and stored with the drive (in a case?)...its a slim model! The whole package should be small and compact. Silicon Power makes a whole series of nice ones that have integrated cable storage...a separate cable that latches on for storage. They're neat. They're rugged. They're not slim. Anyway, I was hoping something on the market like that existed in a slim form factor. No such luck. My solution is somewhat lo-tech, but it works for me, and keeps everything stored away and neat (see pic). It was hard to find an 'angle' USB 3 cable that recorded full USB-3 speeds. BTW, I bought another one on Amazon here, and it was USB 2 speeds, though advertised as being full USB 3 speed. I'm still not happy with the length of the cable I found, I would have wanted another 2-4" (don't we all?). But it does the job.

1|I bought this for 2 simple reasons. 1.) Quoted transfer speed being roughly double a typical external drive. 2.) USB powered. 1.) The transfer speed when writing from a networked Synology DS411+ NAS box was pretty good at an average around 50MBps. Larger files were up around 65MBps (videos) and smaller files (MP3 audio) bottomed out in the 35MBps range. Not the quoted speed, but the marketing speeds are typically for reads, not writes because write speeds are generally lower for HDD's. Plus you have the factor of data coming across a Gigabit Ethernet connection between the NAS and my desktop IC. All in all, I considered it a perfectly reasonable speed. Not perfect, but still good. 4 out of 5 stars 2.) The problem is that I could not get the drive to work from USB power on 3 different computers. The power LED would light and the drive would sort of spin, but none of the computers (2 desktops with USB 3.0 and a laptop with USB 2.0 only) were able to connect with the drive. I was about to seek an RMA replacement when I decided to give it one more go with an external USB power supply I happened to have nearby. Boom, connected immediately with no I/O failures and the data write speeds quoted above. So it works great with an external supply that is not included with the drive, but no dice on USB power. Critical failure IMHO. 0 out of 5 stars Update 2/19: Yeah, it died completely now. Very disappointed with this drive. I've used lots of Seagate products over the years, generally with good experiences, but not so much on this one. Update 9/20: I sat this drive aside and completely forgot about it until now. It is working again, and I now know why it failed in the first place. Based on past experience when something like this stops working, but starts working again later it is usually temperature related. I loaded some SMART monitoring software on my PC and started another large write to the drive. Sure enough, after about 20 minutes, the reported temperature had reached 128 Fahrenheit and was still climbing when I shut it down. This is in a 72 F room with the drive sitting on a USB stick on my desk to elevate it and make sure it had airflow on all sides. Thermal design is clearly a problem on this drive. If it overheats before I can transfer 4TB of data to it, it's pretty useless as a backup drive. I was also dumbfounded by all the good reviews, but then realized Amazon is lumping this drive together which several other Seagate models which have no mechanical relationship to this 4TB Backup Plus Fast drive. If you sift through the reviews, a decent percentage of the 1 stars are for this particular model. The lumped reviews are masking the issues with this particular drive. I would highly recommend steering clear of it. Even if I get a warranty replacement from Seagate, I expect it will work the same and I am well outside any return windows, so I'm stuck with this paperweight.

5|Nothing is worse than that sickening feeling of running out of storage space on your notebook or desktop PC. The 2 terabyte Seagate Backup Plus Slim 2TB portable external drive is a bargain for the peace of mind it provides. I paid a small amount more for 2TB versus the 1TB unit and I'm happy I did. I backed up my 250GB drive on my notebook PC, then also offloaded another 219GB to clear space on my notebook and several other external drives. During the transfer process, I experienced speeds of 11.6MB/second over a USB 3 port in the background while going about my normal work routine in the foreground. The unit produces very little heat during operation at 5,400 RPM. It is also extremely quiet and virtually undetectable against typical office background noise. A single led aperture indicator is the only external evidence of operation and can be turned off it it bothers you. The provided USB cable is about 18" and relatively short compared to some other drives, but I find this to be an advantage. I pack it up in my notebook brief case and I hardly know it's there (it is VERY compact and about 3/4 the size of my iPhone 6 Plus). I used the included Seagate Dashboard to schedule and manage my initial and subsequent backups and feel comfortable that my important documents will still be available if my notebook suffers an unrecoverable tragedy. I'll amend this review in the event that I have to restore my system for any reason. Hopefully this doesn't happen, but in the mean time, I have seamless access to data, a complete backup of my primary PC, and a ton of room back. Next, I'm going to back up both the PC and my new Seagate 2TB drive using BackBlaze. Yes, it's a bit of a belt AND suspenders approach, but losing data is not an attractive alternative. I highly recommend this product to anyone who needs a bunch of space for a great price. By the way, my much older 250GB Seagate Free Agent Go drive is still working perfectly after nearly 6 years so I have great expectations for quality and reliability.

5|A nice size for caring around, so far it has been reliable and is well made. Sleek and beautiful too!
5|I purchased two drives, a 2TB in Black and a 2TB in Red. They will each take the place of two desktop bound external 2TB drives that have been dutifully serving as my Media and Time Machine drives that, until bad sector errors have reached critical mass, have performed quite well for a few years. It's fortunate that they should choose to die now, as I'm also moving overseas and would have hated for them to go a month or two from now while I'm over there. Portable was definitely the way to go for me. I don't need 7200 or 10800rpm drives and I don't want to be adapting bulky wall warts overseas, either. Now, there's a bunch of options out there from Toshiba, Western Digital, Seagate and many other lesser-known brands for external, portable drives in the 2TB range. I've been mainly a Seagate customer for the past 5 years or so because they've proven to me that their products have a long life and perform well. This was for desktop models only, however, and design never played a part because they are all, pretty much, big and clunky boxes that sit and do nothing. A portable drive is a different story, and I think Seagate has outdone itself with this drive. Design. Before I bought the two Seagate models, I had bought a WD My Passport 2TB drive at Staples. It was alright, but it was very thick. Nearly twice the thickness of my MacBook Air at the hinge end. The chassis was metal surrounded in plastic and it looked alright. It certainly wasn't going to vie with the MacBook Air for looks and I think it suffered because it tries. The performance was fine, just what I'd expect from a portable USB 3.0 drive. The real problem with the design, though, was not the thickness but the shape. There was virtually no flat surface on the drive at all. Every edge was tapered and the flat surfaces had some convexing going on. Mine would rock side to side on a desk and wouldn't stay in position in my lap. I looked on Amazon for alternatives and found this. I'm happy to report that, with the sides leading to the bottom are tapered, the bottom of these drives are flat and are made of a nicely textured plastic that feels good and grips well on a desk or a leg. The top is even better, being a piece of aluminium that is completely flat and very good looking. Despite the colour scheme not being derived from Apple, the slimness and choice of materials certainly make this feel as though it belongs in a bag with my MacBook or on my desk next to my Magic Trackpad. It's the best looking external drive I've seen. The light on it, however, feels distinctly Apple. Overall, the design is excellent and, without going to the lengths of moulding a piece of metal over a bare drive (see the Seagate Seven), this is probably as slim as you can expect these drives to get. It's nice to see products that design around the user and still manage to keep it looking good rather than just make it pretty. Performance and Heat. As said, these replace my other drives that serve other purposes and that are just about full. So, first order of business was to copy over the old Media and backups to the new drives. First, I formatted them for Mac. For those who don't know, you can buy just about any drive and use it for Mac, even if it says Windows or PC. This can save you a lot of money. Just open Disk Utility, click the drive, select Format and click Mac OS Extended (Journaled) or whatever filesystem you'd like to use. After that, I just dragged and dropped. From a USB 3.0 drive to another USB 3.0 drive with my Retina MBP, two terabytes copied in a little over five hours. This puts the total transfer speed around 100MB/s. Pretty damn fast. While the files were transferring, I made sure to keep an eye on the heat coming from the Seagate Slims (well, I kept the back of my hand on it) and was pleased to report that neither the metal top nor the plastic bottom got any hotter than my MacBook Air runs on my lap. That is to say, they didn't get hot at all, merely warm, and I don't think there's a hazard here. Packaging. Who cares? Its a cardboard box around a plastic shell. The tape holding the box shut was annoying like the tape on new DVDs and Blurays that never comes off in one pull, no matter how much you use your nail to free it. Included is the drive, a fact sheet and a USB cable. Who needs more? This is a great buy. At (if I remember what should be the numerator and what the denominator) $0.05/GB this isn't the best you can do for 2TB, but it's really close. I'm happy with the performance, the design is stellar and user-centric and I suspect the lifetime of this product will be far longer than the time it will take me to fill these drives and need bigger ones.

5|I cannot express how excellent this product is. For transferring large (1-5 GB) files between this drive and my MacBook Pro (late 2013) via USB 3.0, this drive achieved up to around 280 MB/s peak speeds (150-200 MB/s average). I bought this for my research, but I would LOVE to buy another Backup Plus Fast for my personal use. It's that awesome. It feels pretty sturdy and held up well in my backpack on trip to a conference. NOTES: * This drive is actually two 2 TB drives connected together in a RAID-0 configuration -- the data is split between both drives and is internally recombined before sending the data to the USB port. This is why the drive is so much faster than comparable drives. That said, the drive behaves and appears as if it is a single drive (for purposes of formatting, etc.). Pure genius. * It came formatted NTFS, but I used my Mac's Disk Utility to reformat it to HFS+ (Mac OS X Extended, Journalled). It turns out I didn't actually need to reformat the drive. * The drive came with some Seagate software for Windows and Mac and a warranty document ("Seagate Dashboard Installer.dmg", "Seagate Dashboard Installer.exe", "Warrantee.pdf"). I backed this up before reformatting. * Peak file transfer speeds are reached by performing contiguous data access. Usually this is done by transferring large files rather than lots of smaller files.

4|This 4 terabyte drive actually shows as 3.63 terabytes when you use it. That's just the way of the difference between base 10 and base 2 and nothing to worry about. Allow me to tell a grandpa story here. This puts 4 TB in my hand. This thing is about 1/6 the size of my first 30 megabyte hard drive for an IBM XT. 6 times smaller and orders of magnitude more storage. The drive nicely comes with two cables, one cable is a straight 1 USB to 1 USB for USB 3 ports that deliver enough power. A second cable provides 2 USB connectors for your computer to 1 USB on the drive in case your computer isn't delivering enough power, the second connector to allow it to draw enough power. Having a 5 year old desktop I was a little worried about both USB 3.0 and power requirements but I plugged it into the USB port on the front of the desktop, one port only, and it was recognized immediately and I was able to install the provided software with no issue. As well I tried it on two new laptops, both immediately recognized the drive using the single connector option. So this drive should be good to go on virtually any recently manufactured machine though non-powered USB hubs may present a problem with power. As a USB drive it isn't blazingly fast but the speed is acceptable. The backup software actually resides in memory and updates your backup as files are changed so once the first big backup of your machine is done further backups are invisible and unnoticed if that is how you have allowed the back up software to work. Myself, I like my backup software to provide me with password protected encrypted backups which this doesn't seem to do. That is really my only complaint about the drive. If you want a big amount of portable storage this will do the trick for you! 4 TB in the palm of your hand!!

4|This 4TB portable hard disc drive from Seagate is super fast and completely USB powered so you're not tethered to a power supply! USB 3.0 is part of why this drive is a speed demon, but it is also backwards compatible with USB 2.0 ports (although you won't see the 3.0 speeds.) Another big reason this drive is so speedy is that it is really two 2.5" Samsung 2TB SATA drives that are in a RAID-0 configuration. RAID stands for Redundant Array of Inexpensive (Independent) Disks. There are several RAID levels, which refers to how the data is distributed between the drives. This is RAID-0, which is optimized for speed with no mirroring or parity (no redundancy.) So what does that mean to the user? It means you will get very fast data transfer speeds but if either of the drives should fail, you will lose all of your data since data is written simultaneously onto both of the drives. So does that mean RAID-0 is bad? Nope. It just means that this should not be your primary back up drive and that data written to this drive should be backed up regularly to guard against data loss in the even of a drive failure. The drive itself is surprisingly small and without the need for an a/c power adapter, it's highly portable. The top of the drive is a matte finish aluminum and the sides and base are a matte finish plastic. It ships with two USB cables. One is a Y cable for laptops and computers that can't power the drive via one USB port so you can plug it into two USB ports. It comes with Seagate Dashboard software pre-installed on the drive, but can use your preferred back up software instead. I like the Seagate back up software fine but I'm not especially enamored with the social media applications. So I've loaded mine with movies and family videos (that are all safely backed up) we can watch on the television and it works great for that. I was very gratified to see how quickly I was able to write all that data but I did notice this drive got very hot during the process. You won't want this thing sitting in your lap while it's working. ;-) The drive is really, really quiet and I had to glance at the slow blinking white LED on top several times to reassure myself it was still busily writing. As a side note, it is interesting to me that the 2TB drives inside can be installed in a PlayStation 4 gaming console to double the storage. Of course, it would void the 3YR. Seagate warranty but if you're even moderately comfortable installing a HDD, you could upgrade your PS4 and your laptop storage with the two drives within.
