5|When I was first offered to review this hard drive, I was surprised, since I never heard of 4TB laptop drives in the market. However after seeing the device, it is obvious that this is a small RAID-0 package of two 2TB drives, which provide very fast speeds in a small form factor. One of the best things about "portable" drives is that this does not require an external power supply (like the "external" hard drives), and thus are much more versatile. Even when there are two drives, this is lighter from a regular 4TB external drive. However having RAID-0 comes with both advantages, and disadvantages, and you should know them before investing. - The drive performance depends on your USB3 chipset. For example my desktop could only go up to 200MB/s. But my laptop has a better USB3 system. - Having two drives run parallel means, they will fail at least twice as fast, so do not use this for your only backup. However having a 3 years warranty is nice (it means Seagate actually believes neither of the drives should fail in that period) - Having two drives in a small area also means more heat. During my surface test of the drive, it quickly reached over 60C (~140F) temperatures (this also stresses the drive more, shortening its lifespan) - In case of a failure, data recovery from RAID arrays is much more difficult than regular drives. Nevertheless, as far as I know, there are no 4TB laptop drives in production, and this is the best choice if you want to carry that amount of data in a small package. Just make sure you have another copy of your backups.

5|Of course, it's impossible to know the true value of a hard drive except in the long run -- and it's not yet the long run. Mechanical hard drives don't last forever, of course, and no should expect that. I will, however, update my review if and when this hard drive gives up the ghost. My experience with Seagate drives has been extremely good, I might add, and I have no reason to think this will be different. What comes with the drive? Well, you get a USB 3.0 Y cable (which splits into the drive interface and a USB for attaching other devices. This is helpful as the drive itself has no USB ports. You also get Seagate Dashboard for both Mac and PC. As a Mac user, it's a pleasant surprise to get a hard drive that has a Mac version of anything. Unfortunately, this program doesn't lead anywhere except to a test drive (temporary) of back-up software. Oh well. This drive, by the way, is very small. Much smaller than I expected, and also unexpectedly heavy for its size. It doesn't feel particularly rugged, so I'd be quite careful lugging it around. The weight allow might cause some serious damage to the unit in a fall. Note that this drive doesn't support S.M.A.R.T. diagnostics, so you can't get ongoing diagnostics to know if and when the drive is starting to malfunction. Don't underestimate S.M.A.R.T. It can give you enough time to copy a hard drive before it fails, and the lack of S.M.A.R.T. support is of concern here. Although this is a RAID drive, it is a RAID 0 -- meaning there is no redundancy and, if one of the two drives fails, you've lost everything. (Pieces of files are kept on each of the two internal discs.) In theory, this might mean less reliability because two complicated mechanisms must continue to perform for the device as a whole to function. We'll see how this plays out over time. Without S.M.A.R.T. diagnostics, you may be playing a little fast and loose if you us it as your only back up.

5|I bought a 2TB Seagate Backup Plus Portable Drive (Model STDR2000100 2TB) from Amazon last Friday. It arrived with Monday’s mail to my SW Ohio home. It’s about the size of a pack of cigarettes (volume-wise) and very nicely finished. I plugged it into my new iMac, booted it up, and the drive icon immediately appeared on screen. When I opened it, I found three files visible: Warranty.pdf Seagate Dashboard for Windows.exe Seagate Dashboard for Mac.dmg Since I have no PCs and since I hope to add a boot system to the drive, I chose to reformat the drive with a GUID partition table with the Mac OS Extended (Journaled) file system. The formatting took less than a minute using Apples “Disk Utility” application. [See Seagate article 207851 here: http://knowledge.seagate.com/articles/en_US/FAQ/207851en?NewLang=es&language=en_US . See also Apple Support article HT202380 here: http://support.apple.com/en-us/HT202380 .] However, before I did that, I called Seagate Support: I asked, “If, at some later date, I want to format my drive back to NTFS, could I do that, and would the software that was on the disk when I bought it be available to me online?” I was assured that I could, though I would need to do it from a PC, and the software is available online free. [For the software downloads, go here: http://www.seagate.com/search/?keyword=dashboard%20download .] I also took the precaution of copying “Warranty.pdf” to my main drive before reformatting, and copying it back to the Seagate after reformatting. I then asked what the difference was between the drive I bought and the more expensive Seagate Model STDS 2000100. Well! The hardware is identical. The only difference is software, and that software is available online free. Wow! Wish I’d started asking that that question ten drives ago! [See, "Seagate Dashboard 3.0 How to Setup Mobile Backup Using the Backup Plus as the Destination Drive," and the other Seagate Dashboard videos on YouTube.] Some have asked how hot this drive gets. Mine just now finished copying a 250 GB Time Machine backup file from a Firewire drive (plugged into the iMac’s Thunderbolt port via Apple’s Firewire-to-Thunderbolt converter cable) to my new Seagate drive. The transfer took about 20 hours. My fingertips can barely perceive that the drive is warmer than the room. I’m impressed! Several have reported reliability nightmares with this drive. It’s far too soon for me to have any experience on that, but it does concern me. To protect myself for the next two years, I purchased the, "Seagate Rescue - 2 Year Data Recovery Plan for External Hard Drives," for another $10. So far, I love this drive!

2|I bought this so I could transfer all my files (photos of my when my son was a newborn, important documents, music, etc) from my Macbook that I've had for nearly 8 years, and is about ready to die on me, to my Windows computer since in the description it claims "Use between PC and Mac computers without reformatting". However, after trying to install the Dashboard onto the Mac v. 10.5.8, it kept coming up with an error saying that it quit unexpectedly everytime I tried to open the .dmg file. Finally, I emailed Seagate's tech support and their agent told me this device must be reformatted as the backup device for Mac's Time Machine, which will consequentially erase the Windows compatibility. So, while it works great with my Windows and I will be keeping it to backup all my files (once I use a very time consuming way to transfer my files), I'm only giving it a couple stars because of the inaccurate description. Included, here is the text of my email from their support. *Dear Kaylee Anderson: Thank you for contacting Seagate Support. I understand your frustration. The Dashboard software, even in 10.6.8 or higher, does not backup a Mac. This drive is designed to be used with Time Machine if you want to backup the Mac. Time Machine comes with your Mac in 10.5 or later, so if you are using 10.5.8, it should work so long as you reformat the drive for Mac manually and set it as the Time Machine backup disk. Using the drive to backup a Mac does remove the Windows compatibility unfortunately. Seagate does not have any software that will work with this drive and a Mac older than 10.6.8, any software compatible with 10.7 or higher has to remove compatibility with earlier versions due to how Mac changed the operating system in 10.7 and later. To work with 10.5.8, you will need to manually reformat the drive. The first thing I would suggest doing is to unplug the drive, then plug it back in. This will break the connection to any running programs (often the installer will still try running even when not compatible, and will not let go until it is unplugged). Once this is done, follow the steps on this page to reformat the drive. Reformatting, erasing, or partitioning the drive will erase any data that is currently on the drive, so if you have copied data to it from any other computer, please back it up first, as Seagate cannot recover data lost without cost to you. http://knowledge.seagate.com/articles/en_US/FAQ/207851en Once the drive is formatted for Mac, you can then go to Apple > System Preferences > Time Machine Preferences and set it as the Backup Disk. It will automatically back up the computer to the drive at that point. For additional assistance, feel free to contact us at: www.seagate.com/about/contact-us/technical-support/ Regards, Zach Seagate Support*

5|Bought four of these Seagate Backup Plus Slim, USB-3, 2-TB portable external HDs, from Amazon. Reformatted all four while still in their cases. Bought two, 2nd hard drive caddies; a 9mm and 12 mm., to replace the optical drives. Carefully took the 9mm Samsung Spinpoint 2TB HDs out of the Seagate portable cases. (Details below) Cloned & replaced the stock 17" Toshiba HD to one of these 2-TB drives. Placed another 2-TB drive into the 12mm caddy, and replaced the optical drive in my Toshiba laptop. & viola 4-TB laptop! Did exactly the same thing to my 15" Acer laptop using the 9mm caddy. Both caddys worked as expected, and all 4 HDs were recognized by the laptops. Now both laptops have 4-TB each! Renamed the drives; "2 TB (C)" & "2 TB Movies (M)" Which by the way are practically full! Now; To remove the HDs from the cases, reformat first! Then just use a sharp pocket knife to separate the top aluminum cover, being careful not to cut yourself. Then remove the HD and the plug-in interface together as one unit. Then carefully remove the foil tape from the HD and interface. Then gently pull the interface from the HD. Now you can use the case with any old laptop HD by plugging the interface in the HD, and placing back into the case. Maybe with a rubberband around it to hold it together. Now this Samsung is designed to be pwd by only one USB port. But it only has one USB at the other end. Which is fine for laptops, Desktop computers and USB-3 Devices that have enough power. But if you're going to plug it into a Xbox, PlayStation or Wii you may not have a enough power. Or especially into a aftermarket car stereo USB input. I highly recommend you buy a Y-cable to connect this to your device. The 2-connector Y-design allows you to power the ext HD from 2 USB ports. Great for Wii-U or other devices with low power output USB ports. It's only three bucks here at Amazon. Since I took the 2 TB hard drive out of the case and put it in my laptop, I put the old laptop 1 TB hard drive into the case which I'm sure takes more power than the Samsung 2TB. I believe it took about .85 watts, and most USB-2 ports only deliver a half a watt at best! Not worth the risk of burning out your external hard drive due to lack of power! Now a good question would be what do you do if you only have one USB input port? Well another reviewer already answered that; he plugs in the second USB into a 110v cellphone charger power cube providing 5 volts, or a cigarette lighter USB port to power the second cable. Works like a charm! Priceless!
4|Just got this Seagate Backup Drive, mainly for Time Machine backup for my Mac (since my LaCie has decided to not function again). I'm a little disappointed in that the description indicated the capability of using for both my Mac and Windows computers. Says it will work for transferring files/photos etc back and forth between computers, just not for TM backup AND Windows use. So, I am using it for the Mac Time Machine and if it works well I will order another for backing up my Windows computer. 4|An update: Sadly, I did lean back the other day in my chair, with my laptop, and overlooked that this was attached! It slipped off the desk, dangled by the USB cable, and then stopped working! Now makes beeps, then goes quiet. There are some great videos on the web that show how to take this apart. Sure enough, the head was stuck, but freeing that up has not helped. Now, it just clicks. I wonder if there are other small, external drives that are more fall resistant. I remember reading that the hard drives inside Macs automatically lift the head (or park it) when they fall… that'd be great to have in an external HD. I did notice that, unlike some of the videos of the HD, this had no side bumpers inside the case and no side screws. Assembly line issue? Or, newer design? In any event, as I noted in my original review, the drive is slim, lightweight, and fast-- and a tad noisy. I'm not taking off a star for this (operator error! :-) ), but it's worth highlighting how short the cable is and how smart it is to unplug it after backing up with it! Original review: This is a very fast external drive. It's also small (3" x 4 ½" by '"), making it quite portable (easily "tossed" into a briefcase or backpack). The blue color is great looking. If you're getting more than one of these (as I did) be sure to get different colors, so you can easily tell which is which, especially for a backup rotation. (I got blue and black. The black is fine, but the blue, special, deep and rich.) On the downside, there is a noticeable noise when it's in operation--a combination of swooshing and a higher pitch. I've had other external drives whose noise is virtually undetectable. If your hearing is average or you are insensitive to noises, it's likely no big deal. (Or, if you work in an office or like having music on, those should drown this out.) However, if you have good hearing, are sensitive to noises, and work in a quiet environment, it is a distraction. The USB cord is also short, meaning that the drive is right beside you and your ears (well, at least one of them!). I also could see music aficionados not liking the noise in the background of the songs or classical music they are listening to! I'm in the good hearing, prefer quiet group, but the drive is fast enough (updating backups of, say, 1 gb in about 7 minutes) that it's too bad a problem. One can leave the room or try to ignore it! OTOH, watch out! That short USB cord means that when you lean back in your chair with your laptop, you will likely pull the drive off your desktop! The only solution is to religiously unplug the drive after it finishes its backup.

4|The Seagate Momentus SpinPoint Samsung Seagate Momentus SpinPoint ST2000LM003 2TB 2.5" SATA Notebook Hard Drive 9.5MM hard drives are found in these following models: 1. Seagate Expansion 2TB USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive (STBX2000401) ; AND 2. Seagate Backup Plus Slim 2TB Portable External Hard Drive with Mobile Device Backup USB 3.0 (Silver) STDR2000101; These drives differ in price primarily due to its software and warranty. (Prices are quoted at the time of this review) STBX2000401 2TB is the cheapest because it's a bare backup drive w/a 1-year warranty (~$89). STDR2000101 2TB is more expensive due to its backup software w/a 2-year warranty (~$99). ST2000LM003 2TB is the most expensive being a stand-alone drive w/a 2-year warranty (~$127). I don't know if the sata-to-USB circuit board of the STBX2000401 and the STDR2000101 are any different. They look the same to me. Furthermore, I do not believe the "quality" of aforementioned ST2000LM003 drives differ among those listed above. Why would you purchase the more expensive stand-alone ST2000LM003 over the STDR2000101 even though they both hold the same drive with the same 2-yr warranty? Well because most purchasers aren't savvy enough to remove the drive in the STDR2000101 from its external cover. Moreover, this will likely void your warranty as you would have to remove the half-tamper proof aluminum tape which holds the sata-to-USB circuit board to the hard drive. For folks who plan to extract the drive from its external cover, the warranty issue will be the predominant factor in making this purchase. NOTE: I got the STBX2000401 and extracted the bare drive. Crossing my fingers that the drive will last more than a year to justify my decision to remove it. I've been running this drive for 1 month, and so far so good. I am using this in my Mini-itx build as a SATA secondary drive.

5|Amazing capacity drive. I installed this in a MacBook Pro 17 inch, Late 2011 laptop as the primary (and only) drive. The drive comes with a rather cheap plastic enclosure, no screws. The enclosure is held together by small plastic tabs and (believe it or not) tape, but the drive itself is high quality. The drive will probably be released by Seagate to OEM manufacturers in the very near future, but you can get one now! The drive works perfectly fine as an external backup drive (Seagate's intent), but it also works great as an internal drive. The drive is 9.5 mm thick and so should work with practically any laptop (PC or Mac). Specifically, it will work with all MacBook Pro's which comes with a DVD drive. The newest Mac laptops (MacBook Air, etc.) that do not come with a DVD drive are probably too thin for a 9.5mm drive. In any case, they come with an SSD drive, so you would want to use this drive as an external drive. There is a Youtube video that shows how to get the enclosure open without tearing it up. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I6eV3pEXKgo If you take your time and be gentle, you can avoid tearing up the enclosure and so end up with a temporary enclosure that can be used for other drives (I would not use it an a permanent enclose, because it really doesn't hold itself shut after the first opening). For MacBook Pro users, it is easiest to swap old for new drives if you use Apple's reinstall process on the new drive first while it is in the enclosure, choosing to "reinstall" OSX onto the new drive before swapping the drives around. Some trivia, back in 1986 this amount of storage in a hard drive would have cost in excess of $34 million had it been available as a single unit (it was not).

5|I bought one of these here in Australia for $135 (instead of $180 regular price) with the sole intention of extracting the HDD to use in a laptop optical drive enclosure. There have been many reviews about taking it out an using it ins laptops and PS4's but I thought I'd throw my 2 cents in anyway. To extract the hard drive was a little difficult as I didn't want to damage the enclosure as I had other plans for it. I found that sticking a flat head screw driver in between then jimmying it left to right didn't do much. The trick is to get the screwdriver in between the case and the lid, then to push the screwdriver down until the end of the flat head is touching the top of the lid. Then you'll want to (carefully) push up a bit until you can get the screwdriver in the case itself, then lift the screwdriver until the clips let go. The lid is held down with clips and screws, to the best of my knowledge the clips aren't hard to break and if you happen to bend the metal lid (which I did a bit), it bends back easily. Another thing to note if you are planning to re use the enclosure is it might be useful to remove the glue. Took me 20 mins to scrape it up, but the lid holds on using the clips just fine and it'll be a heck of a lot easier to open it later if you have to. Of course opening the case voids your warranty and I cannot be held responsible for any mistakes or issues you run into, these are just my experience with the drive. Enjoy

5|This special offer was well timed, as I bought this to replace an old 250 GB drive that no longer worked. The old drive was quite large, a hard drive in a shiny metal case the size of a leather Bible. It had its own power cord and whirred like a beehive when it fired up. By contrast, this Seagate drive is same thickness as my iPhone, and only slightly longer. Yet it has more than four times the storage capacity as that old drive. It runs silently, powered only by its USB connection to the computer. It does perfectly what I bought it to do: keeps backups of docs, pictures, music and videos from our desktop and two laptops. Transfer speeds seem adequate, limited as much by the PC and the operating system, but most transfers are simple background tasks while I do other "work." All in all, this was the perfect replacement for my dead drive, and I would highly recommend this to anyone with important computer data and no current backup. It's even small enough to carry with you to serve as a second drive for your laptop.

3|As for 2TB portable drives go this seems to be a great drive. However, as for a backup solution for your portal device - especially iOS - don't bother, look elsewhere. The problem with mobile backups isn't the drive's fault, it's the completely useless mobile app for iOS. And yes, I'm lumping the horrible mobile app review into this product review because this drive touts itself as filling this role when you use the app. So, in essence, they're together as a package. The mobile app, again for iOS, will only backup your camera roll - that's it. I knew this going in but if you're expecting to do a full-phone backup your only solution is what Apple provides, you have to use either iTunes or iCloud. So just be aware of that. The main issue with mobile backup (iOS) is that the app has zero background capabilities. The app must be in the foreground running and the phone must be unlocked. So... the only way to get it to backup anything is to either babysit it (touching the screen to prevent sleep) and not doing anything else on your phone, OR disable sleep mode entirely ("Never sleep"). Since neither of these are practical options the whole idea of mobile backup is a complete waste. The story is likely different for Android but I didn't test it. The drive does come up an NTSF driver for Mac, should you want to keep it in NTSF format (use on both Macs and Windows), so that's a nice touch. You must launch the software to install the NTSF drive, however. Since the mobile backup part of this drive is useless there's practically no difference in what you'd be getting if you just purchased the 2TB portable drive from Seagate, for 10.00 cheaper. Overall: Drive itself is a solid portable 2TB drive... 5 stars. Software to use the drive... 1 star. If Seagate fixes the mobile app I'll consider adding some stars.

5|Good things do indeed come in small packages. I'm mighty pleased with this 2 TB portable drive, which sits pancake-flat on my desk and has a footprint not much larger than a coaster. The drive has a brushed metal top plate melded to a black plastic sides and bottom. I opted for the silver top plate, which turned out to be an attractive but by no means close match with Apple aluminum. When initially connected to a Mac, the user is automatically presented with the option of configuring the drive in NTSC format for dual use with Macintosh and Windows computers, or in HFS+ format for use with Time Machine on the Mac. I chose HFS+ for an additional reason: my desire to encrypt the drive. I accomplished this by choosing Time Machine's encrypted backups option, which actually encrypts the entire drive. I bought this drive in preparation for a road trip that my wife and I are planning. Right now, the drive is configured to accept Time Machine backups of the MacBook Air we'll be taking with us on the trip, and also contains Carbon Copy Cloner backups of our home folders from our respective desktop Macs. I figured that it would be much easier to simply take copies of our home folders with us rather than tunnel in to our desktop Macs from the road, or buy enough cloud storage space to hold everything we might need. If I lose the drive en route I'm out $100, but our data will be safe. The drive is available with a USB 3.0 interface only, which is backwards-compatible with USB 2.0. None of the Macs in my household has a USB 3.0 bus, but the drive's performance under USB 2.0 is satisfactory for my purposes. An 18-inch USB cable is included, which is more than adequate for connecting the drive to an iMac, Mini or laptop. The drive draws power from the USB cable. No AC cord is necessary--or even available. The drive owes its slim profile to the a lack of a power port or an on/off switch. The Seagate Backup Plus Slim portable hard drive is compact, versatile and stowable--it will fit in my laptop case with nary a bulge. If you're in the market for an inexpensive travelin' drive with room enough to hold loads of data, this one definitely merits a close look.

5|When I saw this on a Kindle deal for just 25 dollars, I knew that I couldn't pass up that offer for this kind of space. Just ten years ago, buying a 500 gigabyte hard drive cost me 300 smackers, and it was as thick as a Harry Potter book. This thing is about as wide as my Note 3 phone, and shorter. It's so tiny! Out of the box, I plugged it into a USB 2.0 slot in the front of my computer and it booted right up. The device is preloaded with a few documents, such as warranty information. In theory, you could delete them, but I've left them there just in case. Capacity shows as 931 gigabytes when looked at in properties. Generally, transfer speeds have been around 300-450 per second. I've transferred up to 70 gigabytes at a time onto the device and have not have any problems with freezing. The device does not run hot and remains cool to the touch. I have also run some games directly from this hard drive without any problems, freezing, or slow down. I cannot attest to the software that it comes with, or the mobile backup, as I don't use them. It's perfectly useful as a drag-and-drop hard drive in Windows Explorer. Its portability and plug-and-play capability means that I can take my documents and games to any computer I own. This will be really handy when I move to get a new computer in a few months. From what I've heard, USB powered hard drives aren't so good for use with video game machines, so if you're looking for expandable memory for a Wii U or something, you might want to look into an adapter powered hard drive instead. Overall, I'm really glad I went for that deal, but it's still a good value at regular price.

5|Basic summary: the first 2 TB drive suitable for laptops -- eminently so. It's fast and all but dead silent. I bought this to scavenge for the internal drive (oddly enough, this sells for less than the bare Seagate M9T drive it contains). The fact that I got a compact USB 3.0 enclosure is a plus. I simply copied my data onto it, opened up the case (opens easily enough with a small slot screwdriver to pry the aluminum top away from the plastic bottom, peel back a few pieces of aluminum tape, carefully pull the drive out, pull the USB adapter off the standard SATA connector), put the new drive in my laptop, and put the old one in the enclosure. I replaced the aluminum tape as carefully as I could. The adhesive holding the case together's shot, but it snaps together solidly enough. The only potential problem is whether the aluminum tape is part of the thermal management, and if it will overheat. Worst comes to worst, I roach an old 500 GB disk that I don't care too much about and still come out ahead in the bargain. But at least initially the repurposed enclosure works fine. It's considerably more convenient doing the drive swap without a USB enclosure. While my laptop has two drive slots plus an mSATA, it would have been a multi-step process involving opening the laptop three times to shuffle disks around. The disk itself is all but silent. Even when copying lots of small files onto it and doing a diff (both of which tend to make the drive seek), I had difficulty hearing it even when I tried hard (the drive it replaces is louder). Performance-wise, looks fine. As a SATA drive, the sequential read is a bit faster (128 vs. 106 MB/sec) and sequential write quite a lot faster (98 vs. 57 MB/sec). It's possible that that difference is due to the operating system (mounting USB disks as fully synchronous for safety), though. It's a little faster than the 1 TB drive it replaced, perhaps less so than might be expected, but I'm not seeing any evidence that the firmware was crippled on it or anything.
5|I bought this as a replacement internal drive for a laptop. Inside the enclosure is a 9.5mm 2.5" SATA drive, which is exactly what I was looking for. Many laptops these days only fit these slim 9.5mm hard drives, and they are next to impossible to find in this price range. Running an SSD with this as storage is working out great, and although I had to remove it from the case to install it, I'm happy with the drive so far.

5|never had an external hard drive and I love every bit of Seagate Backup Slim (2TB). It's very thin/small and also pretty fast : I get anywhere between 80MBs - 120MBs via USB3 when copying large files. I have two partitions on it; one for Mac Time Machine backup (MacOS Extended FS) and the other for Windows and everything else (exFat). I haven't run any apps directly off this device -- it's not meant to be used as such. The internal Samsung M9T drives are optimized for large sequential read/write and, in practice, can achieve reading/writing speed of 120+MBs, according to various IO benchmarks out there, making it ideal for backup. Everything worked pretty much out of the box, though it also came with mobile/backup software I never use. The only downside so far is that the case seems to wear and tear quite easily. 5|Wicked fast, small and compact. Use the included Paragon driver for Mac to write to the drive which is formatted for NTFS. The Paragon driver normally costs money, but you get a free version that only works with Seagate drives. The good news is it works with just about any Seagate drive formatted for NTFS, so if you have another seagate it uses the same driver. You can reformat it for Mac but then you can't see it on a Windows computer. I recommend the Paragon driver, I've been using it for years with various Seagate external drives over the years and it works perfectly. Please stop writing "USB3 cable is too short" in reviews for USB3 drives. The length of the cable is dictated by the USB3 standard. It HAS to be that short. Deal with it! Anyway, love this drive, highly recommended. I have an older 500GB version and it's still going strong.

5|I was looking for a 2TB hard drive to put in my notebook and replace the existing 500GB drive. After doing a bit of research I found that this drive was one of the best and cheapest options to do that. This backup slim external hard drive has a notebook drive inside it. How to replace the notebook drive ( I spent 3 days doing this so read up and save some time ) 1. Use Maricum Reflect free edition to make a disk image of your current drive and save it on a different external drive. 2. Make a Maricum Reflect System recovery CD/DVD, you will need this later. 3. Extract drive from segate backup plus slim. To get to it you would need to open up the case (which would void warranty) by using a thin screwdriver and following along the metal plastic edge which is held together with glue. I found a you tube video of it which helped ease my concerns. Carefully slide the drive out of the plastic case. Remove protective metal tape. Hold the drive and slowly pull out the SATA-USB controller on the pin edge of the drive(it comes out easily) 4. Shutdown notebook, remove the battery, remove exiting hard drive, put in the Samsung Segate 2TB drive. 5. Boot from the Maricum Reflect System recovery CD, restore drive image from external USB backup drive. Why do the image restore this way, cause I tried every other way and it didn't work. 6. Boot up normally, then resize partitions as needed. I used MiniTool Partition wizard home edition. This is needed if your old drive is smaller, so restoring the disk image leaves all the extra space as unallocated space. So I made changes to expand my main drive. Restart to make sure things work. 7. Once Windows starts you may start noticing some issues like Windows update won't run, other windows services fail. This issue is that the larger drives that are over 500 GB today use Advanced Format file system. So Intel drivers for the drive need to be updated. The solution is to install Intel rapid storage technology driver. I managed to find this on the HP customer care site. When I tried to get it from Intel directly, my computer failed to restart and I had to do a system restore to a point just before driver install. The one from HP worked (I have HP laptop). This process is not for someone who is not somewhat decent with technology, even then it's a challenge. In the end I have 2TB drive inside my laptop :) Cheers to all the risk takers who did it before me.

5|Since Amazon seems to conglomerate reviews of similar drives of various sizes, I'll start by saying that this review is on the 2TB drive, STDR2000103. PROS: Great little drive. Very fast, very quiet, very cool. In one rough test, based on transferring a single 6.5GB file from a 7200 RPM desktop drive to the Seagate external via USB 3.0, I got a transfer rate of just under 100 MB/s, and a read rate (verifying) of 120 MB/s. The 6.5GB file was copied to the external and verified in 51 seconds. Almost everything you could hope for in an external drive. CONS: Be aware that Seagate used a different cable with a double connector on the micro end. This is a valid USB 3.0 cable, but you are unlikely to have one in your spares box. Unlike most external drives, where a standard USB-to-micro-USB cable can be used in place of the factory cable, with this drive you'll need the special cable. Amazon sells the cables for about six dollars, and it might be worth it to buy a spare if you are prone to misplacing cables.

Yes, it comes with a USB 3.0-spec cable, but don't underestimate the range of equipment that doesn't even offer a USB 3.0 port for either "top" or "side" 3.0 spec cables. Of course, you can buy an add on card for a PC- but, so what? Plug and play USB 3.0 is at least a couple device generations from being "mainstream". The transfer rate over USB 2.0 with this drive should be better than that- not 13 GB per second, but much better. Buy this drive if you need: Portability and a compact form factor Nice capacity relative to its dimensions Don't buy this drive: if you DO NOT have a "device native" USB 3.0 port on the equipment you plan to use this drive the most with

5|Replaced my Playstation 4 HDD with this one and then replaced the external hard drive case with the PS4's 500gb HDD and used that on my PC. The process was a piece a cake. You need a USB storage device that can hold about 1gb because it will ask for the update file for your current firmware so it can format the hard drive for PS4 use. The PS4 was firmware 1.71. Other firmware versions below this may experience problems. To use the PS4's hard drive on PC's you have to format it. Go to control panel > administrative tools > computer management > disk management > plug in the external hard drive with the PS4 HDD like you normally do then Disk management should refresh and show you multiple partitions (volumes). Delete them all > right click the HDD with all the unallocated space > format. I used quick format and it worked fine. You also have to assign a letter to it and it should be recognized as a external hard drive. P.S. It will show that you have like 1700gb -1800gb left, that's because the PS4 uses some of that space for various things + the byte size is measured differently.

5|I was looking for a 2TB 9mm 2.5" drive for my laptop, and there aren't any. Then I ran across this Seagate Backup Plus Slim 2TB External Hard Drive. I ordered one and it works perfectly. Here's what you have to do to use it in a Windows PC: If you are going to use this drive as your boot drive, first you will have to load an image of your boot drive onto it with software such as Aconis True Image, then proceed to the next step. If you are using it as a second drive, it is already ready to go. Next, pry open the case at the seam with the edge of a knife. It is stuck together wit some sticky glue, and comes apart without too much effort. The hard part is getting the first "bite". From there, just work your way all the way around the case. Then carefully peel the foil back that is holding the drive in. (This foil has an adhesive on it, but comes off pretty easily without leaving a residue on the drive.) Just be patient through these steps, and avoid putting any pressure on the drive itself. Once those two steps are accomplished, the drive and controller come out with a little coaxing by prying very slightly on the non-controller end of the drive and case. Then all you have to do is unplug the drive from the controller and mount it into your laptop. Viola! You have a 2GB laptop drive! If you have another 9mm 2.5" drive laying around, use it in your now-empty external USB case by assembling in the reverse order of disassembly. Works fine with the WD drive I put in it.

3|I purchased this after reading various reviews. It had the capacity I liked, was small and lightweight, so it had a lot going for it. On the downside, as one other reviewer has mentioned, it has a thin strip-like LED activity light that pulses when the disk is active. As the previous reviewer noted, the rate at which this pulse occurs is actually quite slow, so you need to look quite carefully for several seconds to work out that the disk is writing. Other disks (Toshiba, I think) use a color-coded LED to indicate whether the connection is USB 2.0 or USB 3.0 as well as showing disk-activity - which appears a whole lot more useful. Overall, however, if you are looking for a small, performant, lightweight 2TB external drive for backups or other portable media uses, this is a fine choice. Just be prepared to stare at its indicator light for a while and wonder whether it is doing anything!

4|For the most part, there's really not a lot to say about this drive in comparison to others. Everything one would expect is here: solid transfer speeds, quality build, svelte looks, and reliability (some will disagree with this last but, in my experience, Seagate is just as good as the rest). What makes this drive a "go to" drive is the size. If you own Seagate's 500Gb Slim, you know what I'm talking about (this 1Tb version is a bit thicker). if you don't, dig around for whatever 1Tb portable drive you have handy. Now, cut the thickness of that drive into almost half and you've got this drive (the actual dimensions are listed below). What makes this drive worth the price (if you can get it on sale) is that you get the same storage as other 1Tb drives, but at half the thickness. For many, this won't matter, and I can certainly understand that. For those who are packing things tight, though, saving 1/4" on the thickness of a portable drive can be a big difference. I can now easily carry this portable drive in it's own pocket my messenger bag, rather than having it rattle around in the larger pocket with all the other doodads that don't have a good spot. Combined with the fact that this drive will run off a standard Micro USB cable (albeit at USB 2.0 speeds), this winds up being a big advantage for "road warriors" and geeks. Is the drive worth the cost? That's hard to say. If you can get this on a decent sale, I would say yes. I have all sorts of portable drives, but since getting this one I find many of them are gathering dust. It's just hard to pass over the tinned form factor for this drive. I will, however, point out that the Toshiba Canvio Slim is more or less the same price, but manages to shave 1/2" off the length. Personally, I trust Seagate a bit more, but that's personal preference (I also like the look of this drive more).

4|* Review on the 1TB Drive * At only 4-1/2" x 3" x 1/2" the drive is much smaller than either the 2.5" (laptop) or 3.5" (desktop) SATA drives. It's also lightweight (5.3 oz) and requires NO external powered. That's right, it is completely powered by your USB port. All of the above makes this drive ultra portable. 1 TB fits in the palm of your hand! Imagine that! (Do be aware that the drives with the larger 2 TB and 4 TB capacities are thicker, perhaps 1" and 2" in thickness, respectively.) I did a test and determined the write speed is about 193 Mbps on a USB 2.0 connection. For the test, I transferred 1000 JPGs (~ 3.5 MB each) from my hard drive to the Seagate Drive. The transfer took 165 seconds. How I calculated the Mbps: (3,990,187,998 bytes)* (8 bits/byte) / (165 seconds) = 193463660 bits per second ~ 193 million bits per second = 193 Megabits per second = 193 Mbps The *theoretical* speed of USB 2.0 is 480 Mbps, so 193 Mbps is really quite good. If you have a USB 3.0 port, the transfer speed will be even faster. --- I've had a 1 TB Seagate drive fail after mere months -- and I lost years of RAW files and irreplaceable memories as a result. To be honest, I'm still peeved. Always have a backup!! Still, I'll give this one the benefit of the doubt. It's compact, fast, and hopefully more reliable than my old Seagate drive. If it does fail again, I'll be sure to update this review.

I open the file and there it was, the serial number. I copied and pasted the information from the file they supplied thinking that my typing was failing me. Same result. Immediately after connecting, the icon indicating “Seagate Backup Plus Drive” appeared. By double clicking the icon, a window appeared showing the pre-loaded contents, including the Dashboard Installer.dmg. On the installation process of the Dashboard, we are asked to register and this time the serial number came pre-filled in the serial number field… and it worked fine! Using the dashboard is quite simple and straight forward. Its interface is reasonably user friendly. This drive is really fast. I recommend it to all users who need and external and portable storage device. If you do not have a MAC to register your device, I do not know how it works in terms of warranty. I hope Seagate will honor the warranty no matter what, as their registration through PC Windows based platform apparently is not completely reliable…

4|This is an "portable" hard drive meaning all it needs is a USB plug into your computer to transfer the data and get power from. That means you don't have to plug in an AC adapter to your wall socket. I prefer these hard drives over the kind that require an AC adapter every time. This will also work with USB 2.0 adapters the speeds for 2.0 transfers are still fast enough for most users at about a gigabyte of data every 30 to 40 seconds. At the time of writing this review to terabyte drives or the highest capacity could find for a portable hard drive. If you want to get a 3 or 4TB hard drive those are the kind that require a wall AC adapter. I gave this drive four stars because of the time of writing this review it was about $15 more than other 2 TB portable hard drives on Amazon. This hard drive is Mac compatible just follow the steps below to format the hard drive for your Mac. If you're a Mac user setting up or erasing this drive up with your computer is super easy follow these steps. 1. Plug in the the drive 2. Open up disk utility found in your applications folder inside the utilities folder 3. Next select the newly plugged in a drive and on the right-hand side you should see partition click on that. 4. Then inside that screen on the partition layout drop-down choose how many partitions you'd like to set up. I generally go with one partition and just use folders to organize my files. 5. Then on the right-hand side you can name the partitions and select the format. If you are transferring video files I highly recommend you choose Mac OS Extended (If you want to use it with Time Machine this is the choice you need to make) as it can handle files over 4GB. Sometimes it's good to make two partitions and one using "MS-DOS fat" or "ExFat" if you might be transferring files to and from a Windows machine. The reason is Windows machines and Macs can read and write to the "MS-DOS fat" format but your files will need to be under 4 GB each as that's the maximum file size it can handle.*** 6. Then click apply and your Mac will create all the partitions you wanted and you're good to go. *** The ExFat format is new to Mac OSX 10.9 Mavericks and doesn't have a 4gb file size limit the "MS-DOS fat" or Fat32 does but not all devices like cameras & digital devices can't read or write to it. I hope this helps and be sure to always have backups of your important data. Take it from somebody was lost a lot of data to hard drive failures always backup and Time Machine is so transparent if you're using a Mac you should be using Time Machine.

5|I am a IT support consultant so I get to use more than a few external USB drives. Newer, older, fatter and more slim. The Seagate Backup Plus 1TB drive provides similar capabilities and form factor to the WD My Passport Slim 1TB drive. Both are fast thanks to USB 3.0 and both are light and small. I don't notice a lot of difference in the drives when just used as external drives. The Seagate Backup Plus comes with the Seagate Dashboard application and 1 year use of 5GB in the cloud powered by Nero (remember them? The folks who sell their CD/DVD burning software from Europe?). Dashboard provides some new things and some that will be familiar to owners of older Seagate external drives. The familiar is the choice of scheduled and continuous backup of data files. The backup application can push these to the drive or the cloud. This is oriented toward data backup rather than maintaining a backup suitable for bare-metal recovery. If you goal is to backup documents, email, pictures, music, and/or videos this may be your ticket. The continuous backup attempts to keep the drive synchronized with files as they get changed on your hard drive. it requires the drive be connected to be continuous. It will try to catch up if it's been disconnected. It seems to work better than the older (several years ago) versions I've tried before. The backup plan (scheduled backup) can be better if you don't want the overhead of the continuous backup while you are using your computer. You set this up and schedule it. If your computer if off when the backup is scheduled it will either be skipped or run when you computer is started again. Probably best for desktops. The cloud storage required a separate sign-up after registering the drive. You get 5GB for one year, then you have to pay., The new (for me) in the Seagate Dashboard is the use of cloud storage, mobile backup, and social media backup. The cloud storage required a separate sign-up after registering the drive. You get 5GB for one year, then you have to pay., It can be accessed via web, Seagate Dashboard, and mobile apps. The Mobile backup is interesting - a way to save images or whatever that you might have on your phone. It can save the data to the Seagate Backup Plus drive or the cloud. I have an iphone so it has built-in non-expiring cloud access with iCloud. While I have not made much use of this feature it has clear appeal and my small amount of use indicates it works pretty well. The social media backup has clear use for flicker, Facebook and YouTube. I am sure that folks who use social media heavily (sometimes I think I'm the only one who doesn't) will find the ability to backup their content useful and can add to peace of mind. Overall I found the Seagate Backup Plus 1TB drive a physically attractive drive with much in common with the WD My Passport Slim 1TB. It's much faster than USB 2 drives but on a par with comparable USB 3.0 drives. The Seagate Dashboard software and the cloud integration are key differentiators and are a step ahead of Western Digital software. It appears to work well. One down side is only a 2 year warranty instead of the more common 3 year warranty for this class of drive. Hope this helps someone.

Although this type of drive is available from many vendors, both name brand and no-name, Seagate has become synonymous with this type of product for many people. For me, Seagate = slim external hard drive. I own several examples of the Seagate GoFlex and BackUp Plus hard drives, and rely on them every day. I have never had a problem with any of the many slim Seagate external units that I own. This example continues that experience. These types of drives have become a commodity product in many ways. But as with all things it pays to find a brand you like and stick with it. The Seagate Backup Plus Slim 1TB Portable External Hard Drive comes with software for backing up, and features a number of options of sharing photos and using cloud storage. 5|I purchased mine on sale at seagate dot com for $54.95 plus free shipping. Even though the description of this hard drive says USB 3.0, it is backwards compatable with USB 2.0. The included back-up software called "Dashbord" wouldn't install on my Windows XP laptop so I called Seagate Technical Support at 1-800-732-4283 and spoke to the Seagate Technical Support agent who told me to install an alternate back-up software program called "Seagate Manager". It works perfectly to back up all your important files, photos, and documents. You can set it up to do scheduled back-ups automatically if you leave the hard drive continuously plugged in or back-up when you plug the drive in once each day, as I do. I first delete the previous day's back up, then run the full back-up and unplug the drive. BE SURE TO LEFT CLICK ON THE "SAFELY REMOVE HARDWARE" ICON THAT IS LOCATED IN YOUR SYSTEM TRAY NOTIFICATION AREA (LOCATED IN THE BOTTOM RIGHT CORNER OF YOUR DESKTOP), AND WAIT A FEW SECONDS FOR THE "SAFE TO REMOVE HARDWARE" POP-UP WINDOW TO APPEAR BEFORE YOU UNPLUG YOUR HARD DRIVE!!! The Seagate Technical support agent also told me about a second VERY useful complete image back-up software program called "DiscWizard". This program creates a complete image of all your installed PROGRAMS, documents, photos, files, and settings, unlike the Disk Manager software which only backs up your documents, photos, and files, NOT all of your installed programs or settings. The DiscWizard software first prompts you to create a bootable CD that you can use to boot up your computer if it totally crashes. Like before, my laptop had trouble creating the recovery CD, so Seagate Technical Support mailed me a bootable CD free of charge to use in case of a disaster. In a disaster situation, you must first plug in your Seagate drive and then place the recovery CD in your CD drive and then reboot your computer and constantly press F12 to choose "boot from your CD drive". Note: some computers may require a different procedure in order to boot from the CD. Consult your computer manfacturer. Once you have restarted your computer from the bootable CD a DiscWizard screen will appear where you will use your UP arrow to choose Seagate Disc Wizard, press "Enter", wait a few moments for the progranm to load, and then click on the "recover" tab. After completion, your computer will be back to normal like it was before your disaster happened with all your programs, files, documents, photos, and settings restored. You ONLY need to run DiscWizard when you install new programs or make other changes to your computer. There is no need to run it every day unless you have made changes to your computer. If your DiscWizard image was created more than a few days or weeks ago, then you should do a restore opeation from your daily Seagate Manager back-up. Now your computer will be completely up-to-date and back to normal as if nothing ever happened. I would highly recommend this external hard drive to anyone looking for the BEST quality hard drive on the market with a TWO year warranty. For the ultimate protection of your computer, I recommend that you install BOTH of the Seagate programs mentioned above. P.S. Since the Seagate external hard drive does not come with a protective storage case, you can buy a very nice genuine all leather case that will fit your hard drive by going to seagate dot com. When you are on the main Seagate webpage, click on "Seagate Store" in the upper right corner and then click on "Sales and Clearance" and search the webpage for "FreeAgent(tm) Go Leather Case 100612595" where it is on sale for just $4.99 with FREE shipping. I ordered one, and my hard drive and connecting cable fit the case perfectly! It provides the ultimate protection for your hard drive and it's very nice looking!

5|Hard to go wrong here. If you are using this as an external drive, this product has 2TB in very small space and is USB powered. The drive itself only takes 0.7-2.3W to operate! On Mac OSX 10.9.2 running the included Paragon NTFS driver, I was able to see write rates in 8-10 MB/sec with USB 2.0. On a Windows 7 Machine I averaged 18 MB/Sec; 14 MB/sec running the latest 8.1 update. I pulled the drives from two of these units (instructions below - photos to be added soon) for use in my laptop. This product is the only way I know of to obtain the 9.5mm tall, 2.5-in 2T Samsung Spinpoint M9T drive(s). Note: the 2TB version has 1 drive, the 4TB has 2 drives. After installing them in my laptop (has 3 internal HDD bays with SATA connections, 1st bay has OS, apps, etc. on 500GB SSD), I tested data txfr speeds. I moved 1.5 TB of data from one drive to another with average speeds of 194 MB/Sec in Windows 8.1. Laptop now has 4.5 TB of hard drive capacity. Have also successfully installed one in a PS4! Next project will be to install one in a Macbook Pro. Great way to get a lot of internal storage space for little money (Purchased early April 2014 for $103.99 directly from Amazon with 2-day Prime shipping). Removal Instructions (WARNING -THIS WILL VOID YOUR WARRANTY - BUYER BEWARE): 1. Obtain small, flat-bladed screw driver and gently insert between the aluminum top and the plastic bottom. 2. Rotate screwdriver slightly to pry the top off. At this point slide the screwdriver around the perimeter and the top will come off. 3. Once the top is off, you will see the top of the internal drive. Carefully remove from the plastic lower without prying or subjecting the drive to significant shock. It is easiest to remove by lifting the side opposite the USB connector. 4. Once the drive is out of the plastic enclosure, you'll need to remove some aluminum tape and wax paper from the drive. Be careful when doing this to avoid ESD which may damage drive circuitry. 5. Once the tape and paper are removed, the USB to SATA board can be carefully removed from the drive. It is an interference fit without any fasteners. 6. You now have a bare 2TB, Samsung Spinpoint M9T drive that is only 9.5 mm tall! Great for laptops and the PS4. 7. Install in your new device per your device manufacturer's instructions. Enjoy!

5|I bought this to use with my PS4 since inside the case it contains the Samsung M9T 9mm hard drive, and I have to say it works great in my system with one drawback though. The PS4 will not turn on from a complete shutdown without delaying the startup. To get this drive to work in a PS4 you can do one of two things, one is just keep the PS4 in standby mode, then it will turn on fine every time. The second is where the problem occurs and you get the BLUE LIGHT OF DEATH (its not actually dead), this happens when you turn the PS4 completely off. If you have to do this then hold down the power button for 6-6.5 seconds and release before it triggers safe mode at 7.5 seconds, this delays the HDMI handshake giving the hard drive enough time to fully power up thus avoiding the BLOD. I have been using this drive in my PS4 and it works great! I just keep it in standby mode and if I ever need to turn it off I just do exactly what I stated above and it works every time. 5|I've been looking out for a larger hard drive ever since my WD 2 TB My Passport's ran out of space... I knew that there would eventually be a drive for my requirements and this drive fits the bill perfectly. (This drive is not a single 4 TB drive, it is really two 'slim' 2 TB drives placed in a RAID 0 array) Benefits: - No need for a bulky power cord - 22mm thick, not the thinnest external drive but it looks nice - Fast, i mean very fast, the RAID 0 array works wonders for it - Enough space for the average enthusiast (I just bought 3) Negatives: - RAID 0 means the data is striped, for the layman that means that the data is split between two drives so the drive spends half the time needed to write or read compared to a single drive. Now while that may seem great the downside is that if one drive fails then all the data is lost. - Power draw, the device needs a lot of power so there is the chance that one port won't support it, luckily the packaging has a normal USB 3.0 cord and an additional USB 3.0 Y-splitter. All in all, an excellent investment for those who need a portable drive with lots of space. P.S. I am not absolutely sure on how this drive will last, especially with the dual drive aspect, but if it does fail I'll be sure to update this review.

5|This hard drive is reasonably priced when compared to other external hard drives on Amazon. Be sure to click through the different hard drive sizes and color options because the time of writing this review the red 1TB hard drive was four dollars more than the black. So with color doesn't matter to you there is some good savings to be had. This is an "portable" hard drive meaning all it needs is a USB plug into your computer to transfer the data and get power from. That means you don't have to plug in an AC adapter to your wall socket. I prefer these hard drives over the kind that require an AC adapter every time. This will also work with USB 2.0 adapters the speeds for 2.0 transfers are still fast enough for most users at about a gigabyte of data every 30 to 40 seconds. Before jumping in to a hard drive purchase be sure to buy the biggest hard drive you can afford as with everything nowadays going digital you will want/need that space in the future. This hard drive is Mac compatible just follow the steps below to format the hard drive for your Mac. If you're a Mac user setting up or erasing this drive up with your computer is super easy follow these steps. 1. Plug in the the drive 2. Open up disk utility found in your applications folder inside the utilities folder 3. Next select the newly plugged in a drive and on the right-hand side you should see partition click on that. 4. Then inside that screen on the partition layout drop-down choose how many partitions you'd like to set up. I generally go with one partition and just use folders to organize my files. 5. Then on the right-hand side you can name the partitions and select the format. If you are transferring video files I highly recommend you choose Mac OS Extended (If you want to use it with Time Machine this is the choice you need to make) as it can handle files over 4GB. Sometimes it's good to make two partitions and one using "MS-DOS fat" or "ExFat" if you might be transferring files to and from a Windows machine. The reason is Windows machines and Macs can read and write to the "MS-DOS fat" format but your files will need to be under 4 GB each as that's the maximum file size it can handle.*** 6. Then click apply and your Mac will create all the partitions you wanted and you're good to go. *** The ExFat format is new to Mac OSX 10.9 Mavericks and doesn't have a 4gb file size limit the "MS-DOS fat" or Fat32 does but not all devices like cameras & digital devices can't read or write to it. I hope this helps and be sure to always have backups of your important data. Take it from somebody was lost a lot of data to hard drive failures always backup and Time Machine is so transparent if you're using a Mac you should be using Time Machine.

To remove the drive you'll have to be patient and slowly pry the edges of the case open using a small utility knife to open an edge and then use a plastic credit card or small screw driver and work your way around the edges. After removing the top the drive and be easily pried out of the case starting at the opposite end of the USB connector. You'll have to remove the foil wrapping with is really stuck to the drive...be patient and work slowly. The USB connector is somewhat hard to remove. Simply use a small utility knife or screw driver to pry between the connector and the drive to start separating the connector from the drive and then pull it off. Voila, a 9.5mm drive. Be advised for Mac users you'll have to use Disk Utility to repartition the drive and select 1 partition and click on options and select GUID partition scheme. Also select Mac OS Extended Journaled from the topdown menu and type in a name for the drive. I used CCC but the restore function in Disk Utility works fine for cloning the new drive to you laptop.

I had to search for the files that were created and manually delete them. Prepare for the scavenger hunt, you have to search through system files & hidden files. -BENCHMARK- Blackmagic Disk Speed Test I partitioned the HD into two separate formats using the GUID partition map. 1st partition is Apple (journaled) format 2nd exFat format(windows/mac compatible). Wrtie & Read (Average speeds in transfers of 1,2,3,4,5GB stress levels) Apple format: Write:~104.3 Read:~105.76 Mb/s exFat format: Write:~54.66 Read:~57.86 Mb/s Conclusion: Obviously the speeds are not what we expect to see for USB 3.0. Comparatively external HDDs on true USB3.0 we could be seeing speeds up to the 124-150Mb/s. On SSDs and extreme flash drives the speeds are around double that - of course, you're sacrificing mass storage to price ratio. Would this information stop you? No, and it shouldn't!! Why? Because Real-Life situations: i transferred a folder with miscellaneous mp4 movies in 720p that added up to 7gigs. The Results: in apple format it took a little more or less than 30 secs and exFat it was around a minute. expect the same timings for transfer rates out of the hard drive since read/write speeds are similar. Even if you are transferring files up to 16gbs it would not take that long. This is still a suitable drive to use as a complete backup drive. The speeds are still faster than USB2.0 by a great amount, think 30Mb/s speeds. And this sure beats uploading/downloading with an online cloud. I took one star off because of useless software(a benchmark software would have been more useful). The other star i deducted because $20 could get you double the capacity. However, that too is subjective if you need that or not. So no one should have buyer's remorse. Besides, by the time you need more capacity well... technology will be something else.

5|How it looks: The silver version of this drive has a brushed aluminum front with rough etched Seagate logo, rest of the drive case is plastic. It is the same silver as a macbook but since it is brushed instead of powder coated it catches a lot more light. Not unattractive. Thankfully the LED light is white and pulses rather than WD's annoying blue led flicker, the thin white light goes off when not used for awhile. Sizing: Compared to an iPhone 5 the Seagate Slim USB3 500GB drive is a little bit thicker (~2-3mm), shorter length wise (~1cm) and wider width wise (~2cm). Speed: This drive uses a standard blue USB 3 cable (included) that is backwards compatible to USB2 meaning that you can plug it into any Mac or PC. Thunderbolt drives are the fastest, but this drive isn't compatible with Seagate's Thunderbolt adapter. USB 3 is fast, but if you connect it to a Mac that doesn't have USB 3 support it will run at the very slow USB 2 speed (ie long file copy times). Unlike PCs which use a blue USB port to indicate USB 3 compatibility a Mac doesn't easily tell you if it is USB 3 or USB 2. You'll have to look up your model specs by going to the Apple icon, choosing about this Mac, more info and then googling your model number for details (surprising this isn't made easier, but any Mac model made earlier than mid 2012 probably doesn't have USB 3 support). It shows up in the Mac finder as "Seagate Slim Drive" with an Orange USB icon drive. It contains a Mac and Windows installer and 400mb of videos (why they couldn't ship a single higher quality MPEG4 with multiple audio tracks is beyond me). The list of files on the drive are at the bottom of this review. Drive is formatted NTFS and has no support for SMART drive sensors or hardware encryption. If you want to optimize it for a Mac only environment or plan on using Time Machine for backups you will need to launch Disk Utility on your Mac to erase the drive. I chose Mac OS extended (Journaled, Encrypted) because I plan on using it to backup my MacBook Air via Time Machine and don't want anyone finding my drive to be able to access the contents (uses software encryption which is slower than WD's version). It should just take a minute to format. If you get the error message: Disk Encryption. Disk Erase failed with the error: Couldn’t unmount disk, then you should make sure to dismount the disk image (drag drive to trash) and try again. You can't be accessing the drive while trying to format it. If you go into Time Machine's preferences you can now add the Seagate drive as a replacement or as an addition. I use my Airport Time Capsule at home and wanted to add this drive as a backup at work so I added both. In the time it has taken me to write this review Time Machine has backed up 7GB of the 72GB needed. Wishing Seagate had a slim thunderbolt drive, but Apple is already onto thunderbolt 2 so I'm feeling a bit behind on this USB 2 only Mid 2011 MacBook Air! 5|My goal with this product was to establish a rotating disk backup system using two portable hard drives. I wanted to back up to one of the drives (kept at home in a secure location) on a weekly basis and rotate it with another drive (kept in an external secure location) on a monthly basis. For this purpose I bought one silver and one black drive so they'd be easy to distinguish. I was able to get this system working but not without a significant effort. The main issue with the Slim drive for my application was that the software supplied with it (Seagate Dashboard) doesn't support disk rotation. After some futile efforts on my own to get Dashboard to do backups in rotation, I contacted Seagate to see what the problem was. They sent me a product key which allowed me to download Seagate Manager (an older product). I took this response to mean that Dashboard definitely does not support disk rotation. As far as I know you can't get Seagate Manager without asking Seagate Tech Support for it; but they don’t seem to mind providing it. How long this arrangement will last I don’t know. So, if you want to do rotating backups you’ll need Seagate Manager. After you download and install it, be aware that there are two more hurdles. First, you must show Seagate Manager the two (or more) drives you intend to use by plugging them into USB ports at the same time. Read the accompanying help file very carefully on how this is done. The procedure seems a little arcane but it works. Once this step is completed either drive may be plugged into either port. The second hurdle has to do with your computer being able to recognize your drives as distinct drives. Some (older, perhaps) Seagate drives may have this problem. If Seagate Manager doesn't show two distinct "lettered" drives on its main screen when you have them both plugged in, you have this problem. I suggest you either contact Seagate or search the Internet for the solution. It involves renaming one of the drives in the Windows Disk Management window of the Computer Management utility. At this point I’ve been doing rotating backups for about a month and am very satisfied with the job that Seagate Manager and the Slim drives are doing. Once you complete the first backup which may take a while, the regular incremental backups go very quickly. The capacity and size are great for physical storage purposes. So, all in all five thumbs up. P.S. I’m also using Seagate Manager to do rotating backups on another computer using Seagate Flex Go drives. Same comments apply.
