5|? Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: ????? Highly recommended with warm fuzzies! ? Positives: ? This hard drive is indeed very slim, with its 9.5mm thickness being comparable to an internal laptop hard drive. ? The read/write transfer speeds are pretty fast for a 5400-RPM hard drive (but performance will feel slower if you are accustomed to using 7200-RPM drives). ? By installing a Windows or Mac driver, you can use either the Windows or Mac version of this drive on both Windows and Mac computers, which is great for transferring files in between both platforms. ? This drive comes in 500-GB, 1-TB, 2-TB, and 4-TB capacities with different color options for the top metal panel. ? Negatives: ? While the Seagate Dashboard software that is pre-loaded on the hard drive includes very useful and flexible backup software, the other two parts of the software to share files to social media sites and save files from social media sites are limited in their usefulness and flexibility. ? If you are relying on the Seagate Dashboard software to backup all of your user files, such as documents and emails, Dashboard will not backup hidden files, so you need to unhide all folders and files in your C:\Users\ folder by unchecking the folders' or files' "Hidden" property attribute. With a thickness of 9.5mm for the 500-GB drive, this very portable little drive is only slightly thicker than an iPhone or pencil, and its thickness is comparable to many internal laptop/notebook drives. But while 9.5mm-thick internal laptop drives do not have an external case covering them, this drive is housed inside an attractive anodized aluminum metal case, with a plastic bottom base, that gives it a solidly rigid feel to the drive. The hard drive that is housed inside the case may even be thinner than a 7mm internal hard drive. So this external hard drive is actually thinner than most internal laptop/ultrabook hard drives. And the 500-GB drive weighs only 5 ounces, making this an extremely portable drive to carry around. With a thickness of 12.0mm, the 1-TB and 2-TB versions of this drive are 2.5mm thicker and slightly heavier than the 500-GB version. But a 12.0mm-thick drive casing is still tiny for a 2-TB external drive. There are some 15mm-thick 2-TB internal drives that are thicker than this, and they do not have an external case. This hard drive comes with an 18-inch USB 3.0 cable. While this cable length is adequate for plugging into a laptop, I wish that the supplied cable was just a little longer in length (24 inches would be ideal) to allow more flexibility when connecting the hard drive to a desktop computer. My desktop computers are connected to USB hubs located on my desk so the cable is not too short for me, but many people will plug this hard drive directly into their desktop computer's USB port. This drive is whisper quiet and when it is plugged into the USB port, a thin sliver of light glows near one corner of the top of the case to show that it is operational. While this drive is either reading or writing data, the glowing light pulsates, slowly shifting between dim and bright, instead of just blinking like most hard drive status lights. The pulsating hard drive status light looks more unique than the usual blinking light used by other external hard drives, as if the hard drive is breathing in and out while it works. My one minor quibble is that I wish the light would pulsate at a quicker pace. With a blinking hard drive activity LED, I can quickly glance over at the light and see if it is blinking. With this slowly pulsating light, I have to stare at the sliver of light for several seconds to see if the drive is reading/writing. As with all non-SSD hard drives, when I hold this drive in my hand, I can feel its body vibrating due to the spinning platter that is inside, and if I press my ear right up to the case while the drive is reading or writing data, I can just barely hear the read/write head moving around inside. So this hard drive is as quiet as the quietest of internal drives designed for notebooks. I have seen various reviews erroneously mention that this Seagate Slim drive is either a 7200-RPM drive or a SSD drive, but both of those descriptions are incorrect. While Seagate previously used 7200-RPM drives in their GoFlex Slim drives, this Slim drive uses a 5400-RPM drive. For a 5400-RPM hard drive though, its transfer speeds are pretty good. This hard drive connects through a USB 3.0 cable, and as with all USB 3.0 devices being backwardly compatible with USB 2.0, you will only get the faster USB 3.0 speeds if you connect this drive to a USB 3.0 port. Connecting this drive to a USB 2.0 port will result in slower transfer speeds. When tested using the "HD Tune" hard drive performance benchmarking tool on an older laptop with USB 2.0 ports, I get an average read speed of 28 MB/s and an average write speed of 21 MB/s. Connecting this drive to a newer laptop having USB 3.0 ports, I get an average read speed of 92 MB/s (with maximum peaks of around 112 MB/s) and an average write speed of 86 MB/s. Even though most 7200-RPM notebook-sized hard drives will be faster, these speeds are pretty fast for a 5400-RPM hard drive. If you want the fastest speeds using this Seagate Slim drive, you need to plug it into a USB 3.0 port. This rule applies to any external storage device that uses a USB 3.0 cable. Perhaps Seagate chose to not include a faster 7200-RPM hard drive inside this tiny thin enclosure because of potential heat and reliability issues? If I read or write hundreds of megabytes of data, the exterior of the drive does get warm over time since there is no internal cooling fan or ventilation holes in this drive's casing, but it usually does not get too hot. On one occasion, however, I was copying many very large HD video files onto this drive, and after twenty minutes of transferring HD videos back and forth where this hard drive was reading and writing non-stop, the drive's enclosure felt very hot when I touched it, so I undocked and unplugged the drive to let it cool down because I was worried about adversely affecting the drive's long-term reliability by continuing to operate it with the temperature inside its enclosure being so hot. The drive enclosure's metal top surface cooled down after about fifteen minutes, and I then plugged the drive back into my laptop and proceeded to edit the HD videos that were now loaded onto the drive. Because this tiny hard drive is housed in such a small totally-sealed enclosure, you should let it cool down sometimes if feels too hot after extended periods of reading/writing data. Avoiding repetitive overheating is a good idea for any external hard drive that lacks a cooling fan or ventilation holes in the hard drive's enclosure since heat can degrade a hard drive's performance and reliability over time. With most electronic components, repeatedly overheating the electronics can cause hardware failures and overheating is the primary cause of hard drive failure. Also avoid bumping, jarring, or dropping this hard drive, especially when it is plugged in. About 800 MB of this drive's space is used up by the pre-loaded Seagate Dashboard software and brief tutorial videos on using the Seagate Dashboard software to protect and back up your files, save social media files, and conveniently share image and video files that are stored on this drive to Facebook, Flickr, and YouTube. If you are certain that you do not ever want to use this Dashboard software, you can delete the 'Seagate Dashboard Installer.dmg' Mac software file, the 'Seagate Dashboard Installer.exe' Windows software file, and the 'Video' folder to free up hundreds of megabytes of disk space. A 'Seagate' folder that is in the root directory contains a 'SerialNumber.xml' file that has the model number and serial number of the drive. The model number and serial number are also printed on the bottom panel of the drive however. In the Windows version of this drive, the 'Seagate' folder has a 'Seagate-Release.exe' program that you can run to register the drive with Seagate. After you finish registering the drive, you can delete the 'Seagate' folder. If you want to leave the software and tutorial videos on the drive, you can still delete either the 135-MB 'Seagate Dashboard Installer.dmg' Mac software file or the 156-MB 'Seagate Dashboard Installer.exe' Windows software file if you only exclusively use Mac or Windows computers. In the 'Video' folder, there are eight folders - 'en-US', 'fr-FR', 'it-IT', 'ko-KR', 'ru-RU', 'sv-SE', 'zh-CN', and 'zh-TW' - that each contain the same set of four tutorial videos: 'Introducing Seagate Backup Plus', 'Protecting Your Files With Seagate Dashboard Tutorial', 'Saving Social Media Files With Seagate Dashboard Tutorial', and 'Sharing To Social Media Sites With Seagate Dashboard Tutorial'. These eight sets of videos are identical in the video and audio, and only differ in the subtitle language used: English (no subtitles), French, Italian, Korean, Russian, Swedish, Chinese, and Taiwanese. If you keep the 'en-US' English video that has no subtitles and delete the other seven folders, you free up almost 350 MB of space. Of the three components in the Seagate Dashboard software, the "Protect" function offers the most usefulness and flexibility, while the "Share" and "Save" functions for sharing/uploading to and saving from social media sites are limited in their capabilities. With the Dashboard's "Protect" function, you can schedule backups of your files based on a regular hourly/daily/weekly/monthly schedule, or have your files backed up whenever they are added or modified, or make backups on an as-needed basis by manually initiating a "snapshot" backup of your files. I am always surprised by how many people never back up the files on their computers, either their work-related files or their personal files, including documents, email and Microsoft Outlook files, photo/music/media files, or other files that are often irreplaceable if their computer's hard drive suddenly fails. If your computer has years of files accumulated on it that you have never backed up to another disk, to a CD/DVD, or to an online cloud-based backup service, this Seagate Slim hard drive can be used as your backup device where you can store a duplicate copy of all your important files. If you have already been using a backup process, as mentioned, you do not have to install the Dashboard software and you can just completely delete all the pre-loaded software from this hard drive if you want. Important Note About Backup Software In General: If you do use the pre-loaded Seagate "Protect" software to back up your files, or if you use other kinds of automated backup software, you should randomly spot-check some of the duplicated backup files and folders every one or two months to verify that the files are correctly being copied and that they can be read correctly. Spot-check the backup files more frequently if they are important and you really value their integrity. Backup software is still a software application and, just like firmware and other software, and also taking into account that a hard drive may start to slowly fail with read/write errors after years of usage, there may be a software or hardware glitch that causes a file to either not be backed up by the backup software, or to be backed up but unreadable. By occasionally spot-checking the integrity of your backup files, you reduce the possibility of having an unpleasant surprise if you really need to recover the files from the backup copy. A data error can happen with any electronic storage media. For example, if you back up files by burning data to a CD/DVD/Blu-ray disc, you should spot-check their integrity by accessing some of their files at least once a year. The same rule applies if your backup files are stored by a cloud-based backup/storage service. There are also integrity-checking software that will automatically verify the integrity of hard disks or optical media. I am an avid photographer, and with terabytes of hard disk space becoming more inexpensive each year, my favorite way to back up files is by manually copying files and folders to two separate hard drives in a "manual RAID 1" setup where I manually back up and mirror the photo and HD-video files onto two separate drives, instead of relying on backup software to perform the function. I previously used a dual-hard-drive RAID 1 storage unit, but I like being able to directly access either drive and I also do not like how RAID 1 simultaneously deletes files from both drives if I ever type or click too fast and have an "oops" accidental file deletion. Important Note About Using Seagate Dashboard For Backups: As stated in the User Guide for Seagate's Dashboard backup software, Dashboard will NOT backup and save the contents of the 'Windows' and 'Program Files' directories, any other system-related files, files stored on detachable USB drives, and hidden files. By default, unless you have explicitly saved your documents and email files in a different location, Microsoft Windows stores all of your personal user files in a folder like C:\Users\YourUserName. This folder location can be accessed, either via the Command Prompt or using the Windows environment variable %UserProfile%, so you can go to your user profile by entering `cd %UserProfile%` in a 'Command Prompt' window; this location is usually C:\Users\YourUserName. Inside your C:\Users\YourUserName folder, there are two important folders called "Documents" and "AppData" where your various data files, document/text/work files, and email files are stored. Seagate Dashboard will not backup files and folders in your C:\Users\YourUserName if they have the "Hidden" attribute turned on. If you want hidden files in these two folders to be backed up, perform these steps: (1) Either from the Windows/File Explorer options or by searching for "folder" from the Control Panel, access the 'Folder Options' and turn on the 'Show hidden files and folders' option. (2) Open up Windows Explorer or File Explorer. (3) Right-click on both the "Documents" and "AppData" folders in your C:\Users\YourUserName folder and select "Properties". (4) On the Properties pop-up window, uncheck the 'Hidden' Attribute box, click [Apply], and also select the option to apply the action to all subfolders and files. (5) View the "Properties" for other folders and files stored in other locations to see if their 'Hidden' Attribute is checked and repeat this same procedure for those hidden folders/files that you wish to back up. Versions of Microsoft Outlook prior to Outlook 2010 store your PST email files in: C:\Users\YourUserName\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Outlook\ and your "AppData" folder will need to have its 'Hidden' Attribute unset for those email files to be backed up. Later versions of Outlook store PST files in C:\Users\YourUserName\Documents\Outlook Files\, which is typically not hidden and will be backed up. The Dashboard software's "Share" function lets you share files that are stored on the hard drive by uploading to either Facebook, Flickr, or YouTube. And the "Save" function lets you save photos from Facebook or Flickr. Unlike the "Share" function, "Save" does not let you save videos from YouTube. But there are many freeware software and online sites that can convert and save YouTube videos already. I really did not care for how either these "Share" or "Save" functions worked because they are quite limited in their flexibility, and it is very easy to perform the same functions directly using the Facebook, Flickr, and YouTube sites without having to go through an intermediate step of using the Dashboard software to upload files. Perhaps Seagate added the "Share" and "Save" options for computer newbies or social media newcomers. But the irony is that even though this Dashboard software "dumbs down" the uploading of files to Facebook, Flickr, and YouTube, the computer newbies who would most benefit from using the "Share" and "Save" options may not even have an account on Facebook, Flickr, and YouTube. This pocket-sized drive is quite small and light: 4.5"x3.0"x0.4" and 5.3 ounces (including the USB cable) for the 500-GB version, with the 1-TB and 2-TB versions being slightly thicker and heavier. You can use this portable drive to shuttle files back and forth between Windows and Mac computers, dragging and dropping folders and files to transfer them between the computer and this external hard drive. Note that there are two versions of this Seagate Slim external hard drive: a Windows version formatted for NTFS and a Mac version formatted for HFS+. You should get the version for the platform that you work on the most. If you mainly use a Mac and you use Time Machine for your backups, you should definitely get the Mac version of this drive. If you mainly work on Windows and Mac is more of a secondary computer, you should get the Windows version of this drive. Since Windows NTFS and Mac HFS+ file systems do not automatically play well together, use of this hard drive on both Windows and Mac computers does require the download and installation of a driver. If you get the Windows version of this drive, when you plug the drive into a Mac, it will download from the Internet a necessary Mac driver (NTFS_for_Mac_with_restart.dmg) that lets the Windows-NTFS-formatted drive work with Macs. NTFS drives are normally read-only on Mac OS, and this driver lets Macs both read and write on the NTFS-formatted version of this hard drive. Note that because Mac's Time Machine requires a Mac-HFS-formatted drive, when you use the Windows version of this drive with the Mac driver, this setup cannot work with Time Machine unless you reformat the drive to be a HFS+journaled file system... in which case you might as well just get the Mac version of this drive if you intend to also use it with Time Machine. If you get the Mac version of this drive, when you plug the drive into a Windows PC, it will download a necessary Windows driver (HFS4Win.exe) that lets the Mac-HFS+formatted drive work with Windows. You can also download both the Mac-driver-for-Windows-NTFS and Windows-driver-for-Mac-HFS+ drivers directly from Seagate's Web site. See the 'Comments' section of my review for the URL locations. Seagate should have pre-loaded both of these Windows/Mac drivers on the hard drive just like how they pre-loaded both the Windows and Mac versions of their Dashboard software. Overall, this is a great little drive that is sized for maximum portability. It includes a 2-year limited warranty. And at the time of this review's writing, Amazon is offering this hard drive at a great price of less than $70 for the 500-GB size. It was not that long ago when a 500-GB portable hard drive costed hundreds of dollars and was at least three times larger in size. If you have questions, please ask.

5|- IT'S A BEAUTY I received this ultra compact 2.5" external hard drive drive through the Vine program. This ultra-book is an all-USB 3.0 model and I used one of the 3 available USB 3.0 ports to provide a directly cabled connection to the Seagate Slim. - THE TEST: SMALL FILE TRANSFER TEST (SMALL FILES ARE A GOOD TORTURE TEST THAT ALL EQUIPMENT HAS TROUBLE WITH) 1GB worth of 4KB (small) files transferred: - From the computer's internal hard drive to the Seagate Slim: 5 mins 25 secs - From the Seagate Slim to the computer's internal hard drive: 1 min 40 secs . . LARGE FILE TRANSFER TEST (LARGE FILES ARE EASY FOR ALL EQUIPMENT) A single 1GB iso (large) file transferred: - From the computer's internal hard drive to the Seagate Slim: 25 secs - From the Seagate Slim to the computer's internal hard drive: 35 secs . . THIN IS IN I'm normally interested in capacity and performance - usually in that order. Under those criteria, this drive wouldn't normally rank very well. After all, there are much higher capacity portable drives: the Western Digital 2TB passport is one that I frequently use when I am looking for high capacity. And there are faster drives available: anything spinning at 7200 RPM or higher is likely to be a bit faster. But, the thin and light nature of this drive begs for it to be paired up with the ultra-book. They just look right together. You carry an ultra-book to travel lightly and therefore an ultra-slim hard-drive fits right in to the motif. The Seagate Slim offers good performance at a moderate capacity point in a very thin enclosure. - COLOR CHOICES In addition to the black model (Model No. STCD500102) that I reviewed, Seagate makes this drive in a silver finish (Model No. STCD500104). - CONCLUSION It all comes back to capacity: is 500GB enough? I want to say 'yes,' but it would take a 1TB capacity drive for me to say 'definitely.' If you can be satisfied with 500GB and want a thin enclosure, then the Seagate Slim is probably the drive for you. It has good performance, is super-light, inexpensive, and very compact. I'm considering trimming down some of my data and making the Seagate Slim my D: Data drive for use with the ultra-book. They would go very well together. - ALTERNATIVES If you need: - 256GB capacity and an even more compact form-factor, I would recommend the Patriot Supersonic Magnum thumbdrive. - 512GB capacity, faster speed, and an even more compact form-factor, I would recommend an mSATA SSD in the MyDigitalSSD Bulletproof enclosure. - 500GB capacity and faster speed, I would recommend the Oyen U32 Shadow 480GB SSD. - 1TB capacity, I would recommend the Oyen U32 Shadow. The Shadow is 1.5mm thicker, slightly longer in length, and slightly narrower in width. The weight is only slightly more. - 2TB capacity, I would recommend the WD My Passport. .

Performance This little hard drive is compatible with USB 3.0 and backwards compatible with any standard USB (like 2.0) outlet your computer may have. That being said, 3.0 is currently the fastest USB port available. So it is nice to have that option to optimize speed. Even though this was a 500GB hard drive, mine came with 465GB of actual space for additions due to the firmware and software previously installed. However, do not be discouraged as this is standard for all externals. When running on a 2.0 port, I was able to download about 23GB in 10 minutes. Ease of Use There is no special software needed to run this hard drive and it is compatible with Windows and Mac. You simply plug this into your computer, your computer should automatically install the needed driver software, and you should be good to go. To put content on the drive just drag individual elements, NOT folders. Folders only will copy the shortcuts and they do not carry content. Value and Final Thoughts If size is a concern, you may want to pay extra to have a really sleek hard drive that can fit in small places without getting damaged. If I do, I will call the nice people at technical support, 1.800.SEA.GATE, to assist me. I called them when I had to reformat my huge SeaGate 3TB Desk Top Hard Drive ] in order to operate it with my PC. The gentleman walked me through the process, which required no more than ten to fifteen minutes to accomplish. I was ecstatic with their free service. All I had to give them was the S/N of the assembly which can be found on the hard drive's box or on the hard drive itself. One of the first things I did after receiving my new STCD500102 and ensuring that it was operating properly was order a case to protect it. I chose the same CaseCrown Brushed Hard Cover Case I bought for my STBE500100 ]. It has plenty of room for the hard drive, 3.0 USB cable, quick start guide and two-year warranty booklet. The case will give me confidence that my STCD500102 is being protected whenever I take it home with me for the holidays. The case fits perfectly inside my JanSport backpack. As I stated earlier, I now own four hard drives from SeaGate. None of them have ever crashed, become corrupted, or died; the computer continues to recognize all of them. I have learned from SeaGate certain practices to follow to keep from damaging a SeaGate hard drive or any other hard drive. When not being used, the hard drive should be kept in a protective case. Never drop, step on or violently shake the hard drive. Never use a long cable to connect it to the PC or Mac. Only use the cable that came with it or a standard one--never one that is six foot or longer (Belkin Pro Series USB Device Cable 16 Feet). This is one of those rare cases where longer is not always better. Furthermore, never connect the hard drive to your PC or Mac via a hub (Belkin High-Speed USB 2.0 7-Port Hub). I did this with several flash drives and they became corrupted. It won't always happen but it might. Also, I just recently learned that before disconnecting the hard drive, one should right-click on the hard drive's icon and choose "Safely Remove." This will always ensure that files are not corrupted. If a flash card, flash drive or hard drive becomes corrupted and needs reformatting, everything stored on it will be wiped off. Joseph B. Hoyos
5|Six months ago I had purchased "Seagate Backup Plus 1 TB USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive STBU1000100" and overall I was quite pleased with it (and I still am.) You will not get a similar transfer speed over a network, unless you have a Gigabyte (wired) LAN. I do, but even then the transfer only averaged 16 Megabytes per second. This is the so called network transfer overhead. I do not use portable hard drives for computer backups. (If all you need is to back up your files on some computer or computers, get a desktop drive. They hold more data and they are faster, and they are also cheaper per Megabyte.) I move my portable drives amongst many computers, some at home, some at work. If you don't care about partitioning your disk, you can stop reading here. My first task was to partition the slim drive to four: one NTFS, two Linux Ext3, and one FAT32 partition. All Windows flavors auto mounted the NTFS partition, and two out of three ignored the FAT32 partition initially. Then I went back to the Partitioning program, and I assigned a Windows drive letter to the FAT32 partition, after which all Windows flavors auto mounted it by simply detecting it. Windows OS (of any flavor) ignores Linux partitions. In contrast, in Linux I can access (read/write) all partitions, but they are not automatically mounted under /media in some Linux flavors. When that happened, I had to mount them by hand; no big deal, but a nuisance. I also encountered another nuisance, which was also common to the larger drive I had bought six months ago: Windows' "safely remove hardware" tool was unable to unmount the partitioned disk. In fact Seagate support personnel had commented on my original Amazon review telling me pedantically: "If Vista is not allowing ejection of the drive by the safely remove icon it generally indicates that some other program is trying to access the drive at the time of the ejection request." No kidding! But of course there was no other program (or open window) which was trying to access the drive at the time. This was a completely useless (but well intentioned) comment. I think the answer is somehow related to partitioning. This problem does not occur if you never partition the drive. I will ignore the minor nuisances, and give it five stars!

Pros: * Front shirt pocket size * About 5 times faster than USB 2.0 if you have a USB 3.0 port * included USB 3.0 cable is right size at 18 inches Cons: * None, really. Some software issues, but you choose (discussed below) To use a USB 3.0 device to its fullest capacity you need to have a USB 3.0 port. You can still use this with USB 2.0 ports, but read/write speeds between the two ports is about 5:1 (i.e., this runs about five times faster on USB 3.0 than 2.0). I tested this on each type of port on the same machine: my laptop. USB 3.0 Read Speed = 140 Mbytes/second USB 2.0 Read Speed = 26.4 Mbytes/second USB 3.0 Write Speed = 100 Mbytes/second USB 2.0 Write Speed = 19.5 Mbytes/second My built in hard drive had a read speed of 162 Mbytes/second so this is very close to the same speed as my built-in hard drive. Note that USB 3.0 specs tout that this should be 10x faster than USB 2.0, but due to all sorts of hardware issues nobody gets that kind of increase in the real world. Five times faster is VERY good and noticeable. The included Seagate Dashboard was cleanly removed after testing, so give it a try and get rid of it if you don't like it. You can get standard USB 3.0 replacements for less than $10 such as this AmazonBasics USB Cable - 3.0 A Male to Micro B (6 Feet / 1.8 Meters). Protect: You can schedule backups at specific intervals like hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, etc. Or you can select continuous backup which basically creates backups in real time as you add or change files. If you don't want to set a regular schedule you can instead click the "snapshot" button to start a backup whenever you want. The first time you run backup takes a little longer because it is backing up all the files, after the first time its faster because its only backing up new or changed files. I have the drive connected to a USB 3 port and the first time I ran backup it took about 20 - 30 minutes to backup roughly 100 gig of data files. The first time you access one of these sites you have to enter your account log-in information and give the software permission to access your account. Here is how it worked for YouTube. Once logged in it brought up a file manager screen where I could browse to and select a video on either my Seagate external hard drive or my computer hard drive. Once the file is selected you choose one of the standard YouTube categories for it. Then the file uploads. After uploading the video using the Seagate Dashboard, I deleted it from YouTube and uploaded it again using the standard upload directly from the YouTube site - just to see the difference. First of all the video took longer to upload using the Seagate Dashboard than it did directly from the YouTube website. I suppose that might not be the fault of the software - maybe the internet was just running slower when I used the Dashboard, but I did upload them within 1/2 hour of each other. The biggest fault I found using the Seagate Dashboard to upload videos is that you don't get any of the options that you do when you upload directly from the YouTube site. When you upload a video directly from the YouTube site you get a lot of options. You can enter a Title for the video, you can enter a description, and enter tags (e.g. Chicago, dogs) so that the video comes up in searches, you can pick a thumbnail to use for the video, select a privacy setting (public or private) and select a category for the video. When you use the Dashboard, it automatically uses the name of the file as the title of the video (you don't get to choose). The only choice the Seagate Dashboard gives you is to select a category for the video - that's it. It also automatically posts it as a public video. You don't get any other choices or options. Once you have uploaded a video using the Dashboard you can always log on to your YouTube account directly from the YouTube website and edit these choices, but why bother with 2 steps if you can just do all this directly on YouTube in the first place? Given the results of this test, I would not use the Seagate Dashboard to upload videos to YouTube. I can't speak for how Facebook or Flickr uploads work because I don't use Facebook or Flick. I would have rated the drive higher if it hadn't been for the software. I just got the drive, so I can't speak for durability, but it seems like well built little drive.

(With the Windows version, there is only one partition to unmount so reformatting is straightforward. However on the Mac version, there are two partitions, both of which must be unmounted prior to the reformatting.) That partitioning achieved with nothing out of the ordinary, I then transfered some folders/files to each of the drives. That too proceeded uneventfully - and FAST. These drives are as good as any I have ever owned yet are much smaller in physical size. It is amazing to me what can be packed into such a small device! Both come only with a two-year warranty; this is somewhat disappointing as many of my other drives come with three-year warranties. Nonetheless, two years is better than the one year warranty with which some drives are now shipping. I like both of these drive very much and I highly recommend either one of them (or both!) to any GNU/Linux user who needs a backup for his/her folders, files, photos, music, etc. Thank you very much for reading this and for considering my opinions.

4|Seagate have a great reputation (on the whole!) as a hard drive manufacturer, so how does this 4TB portable drive perform? Positives: ====== - Powered directly by the USB connection so no separate power supply/cable needed. - Extremely quiet in use, even when transferring data at full speed. - Smart case design, in a mix of gloss and matt finish black plastic. - Supports both USB 3.0 and 2.0 standards. - Comes with 200GB of free space on Microsoft's "OneDrive" cloud storage for 2 years, subject to online registration (which must be done by June 30th 2017). - Plug-and-play on Windows 8.1 64bit and Windows 10 64 bit (i.e. no drivers needed). - Fairly good average transfer speeds. When tested on a Windows 10 64bit PC with a USB 2.0 socket, I got an average of 27-28MB/sec write speed and 33-34MB/sec read speeds when transferring large files of around 4GB in size. That's nowhere near the theoretical limit for USB 2.0 of 60MB/sec, but that could be because the USB controller is optimised for the newer USB 3.0 standard. Other reviewers have reported much higher transfer speeds on newer USB 3.0 machines, so I can accept that this is just because my PC is getting old. These speeds are still pretty good. Negatives: ======= - Slightly bulkier than the average 2.5" USB drive - noticeably deeper by a few millimetres, probably because it has 2 disk platters inside rather than 1. I'd recommend the Black Case Logic QHDC-101 Hard Drive Case, which is a good (if slightly tight) fit for this drive with just enough room for the supplied USB cable. It's still very compact for a 4TB drive, but it won't fit in all standard cases so keep that in mind. - The supplied USB cable is very short at around 14" so it may not reach if your PC/laptop is not very accessible. - There are no rubber feet on the bottom of the case, so it will slide around easily on smooth surfaces and you should place it down gently to avoid any shocks. - The accompanying Seagate Dashboard software is lacking a key feature that I use all the time on my other drives: drive lock password protection. My old Western Digital My Book Elite Edition 1TB Drive from back in 2010 came with free WD SmartWare software that provides a simple drive lock capability that prevents the drive from even being recognised within Windows without the right password. Obviously you can still encrypt individual files using any standard software tool before copying to this drive, or encrypt the entire partition using something like TrueCrypt, but it seems ridiculous to me that a drive intended to store backups does not provide even basic password protection facilities. If you lose this drive or it gets stolen and you haven't taken your own encryption precautions, you can kiss your data goodbye. Disappointing. Notes: ==== - As with *all* hard drives, the free space reported within your operating system will be significantly less than the capacity described by the manufacturer, due to the different definitions of a Megabyte! Just Google it if you want the details. My Windows 10 64bit reports a capacity of 3.63TB for this drive, as opposed to the advertised capacity of 4TB. This is *not* a fault or anything specific to this drive. Summary: ====== This drive seems pretty good value for a 4TB portable (although you should check out the Samsung M3 Slimline 4TB USB 3.0 Portable Hard Drive if you want to compare a very similarly priced alternative). I didn't find any real problems or reasons to avoid this drive, other than the rather basic feature set of the Seagate Dashboard software with no built-in password protection. I think most people would be very satisfied with this drive as a day-to-day storage or backup solution. It's too soon to comment on robustness or longevity but assuming it lasts a few years this should be a good investment. It gets a solid 4 stars from me.

5|I used to be one of those optimistic individuals who thought that "backing up" a computer was just something that techies folks did. Then, about half way through a Masters degree course in 2004, my Mac went into a permanent sleep and I lost all my data. That included movies, animations and sound files, all created by me, so there was no possibility of simply downloading them again and - as I had never done a proper back-up - I was royally stuffed. After many, many hours of unnecessary extra work I was back where I had been months before, and the first thing I did them was buy two back up drives and make sure I copied everything from that point on, twice. I relate this short tale simply to point up how essential I think that back-ups are. I have, over the years, become something of an expert on back-up discs - and was really pleased to have the opportunity to review this diminutive Seagate drive. It really is tiny and slim, and - as you can see from the photograph I have uploaded - it is not much bigger than an iPhone 3. It is pretty much a 'plug-n-play' device, and you can either use it as a Mac and PC or as a Mac only drive. I tried it as a Mac/PC drive first and it worked fine on a range of laptops (Sony Vaio, Toshiba Satellite) and then I wiped it and hooked it up to the 'Time Machine' facility on my MacBook Pro. It took about 6 hours to back up around 300 GB of data in Time Machine mode, but my Mac only has USB 2, so USB 3 should be faster. Depending on which review you read, USB 3 should be anything from 3 to 10 times quicker. It is also small and innocuous enough to slip into a bookcase or somewhere else - well away from your computer - so that it can be used to reclaim data in the unlikely event that your computer is lost or stolen at some point. I have had a laptop stolen from my suitcase on a train, and I can tell you it is a lot less traumatic if you have all your data safely backed up and ready to load straight onto your replacement machine. Back in 2004 my first external hard drive backup devices cost several hundreds of pounds each; these days you will get change from a hundred pounds for a really good quality and small drive like this one. One point to note is that the connector cable, whilst being very good, as it carries everything you need (Data and electricity) in one cable, needs to be kept in a safe place, as it is not a 'standard' USB fitting.

4|Purchased this just over a year ago and I'm quite happy with it. In fact, I've just purchased the 2 terabyte version. However, I did encounter problems that others should beware of. I needed it for backing up my Windows Vista PC, which only has USB 2 ports. I accepted that I would not get the benefits of the drive's USB 3 status but did not expect it to be too bad. However, my backups turned out to be considerably slower; taking over 4 days in fact! I purchased an Inateck PCI-E USB 3 Expansion Card, hoping to resolve the problem. In one sense it did. Backups now took around 4 to 5 hours. Unfortunately, after a few successes, the PC kept losing its connection to the drive. As this did not happen straight away, I suspected that it was a heat problem somewhere. I was getting the same problems, when I was copying a large number of files to or from the drive. I guessed that it might be that the drive and expansion card were struggling with power. The drive does not have its own power supply and I suspected that it was not getting enough power from the card, so I purchased an Inateck Mini Portable 4 Port USB 3 Expansion Hub with its 5V 4A Power Adaptor. I have not had any problems since and my backups seem to have been even quicker. If you are thinking of buying this drive, think about how you expect to use it. If usage is likely to be heavy, either factor in the extra expence of the additional hardware that you might need or buy a more expensive drive with its own power supply. In the end, I am quite happy, because I would probably have wanted to buy the card and the hub some time anyway.

5|The Seagate slim is a very neat compact USB 3.0 drive not much bigger than a pack of cards. It is described a 500GB but I can only see 465GB. I cannot find any hidden partitions etc. The USB 3.0 cable is included. When first using the device you can install the Dashboard but this is not necessary if you don't want to and you can just get on with using the device. The dashboard basically gives the user 3 "extras". Firstly backup software. There are several options for backups that allow the user to select the files and whether the backup is continual etc. The backups are done in a standard format so they can be viewed and accessed by any computer through windows explorer. I do not intend to use this feature as I have other backup software that suits me. The other two extras are for saving to and from Social media sites such as Facebook. I can't comment on this as I do not use any of these social sites. On first use you are prompted to register which is very quick but took me 6 minutes as I went on a tour of the Seagate website looking for updates. Updates can be accessed through the dashboard. If you provide a valid email address then you are sent a confirmation email with a link to one year's free cloud storage. Without actually signing up for the service it was difficult to find the second year costs and also the first year free allowance. On the Seagate site I did find the cost of additional storage which stared at $19.99 for 10GB. The USB 3.0 is not surprisingly faster than USB 2.0 and I just ran a few comparisons of my own on an Acer laptop. These are just rough that I achieved and obviously others may get better or worse results. A 25Gb folder of mixed files Seagate to Acer on USB 3.0 took 7 minutes with a transfer speed of about 60MB/second. Seagate to Acer on USB 2.0 took 15 minutes with a transfer speed of about 30MB/second. The times for the same folder to be sent from the Acer to the Seagate were pretty much the same. A window did pop up when the drive was connected to a USB 2.0 port advising that it would be faster on a USB 3.0. A one hour video file (550MB) Seagate to Acer on USB 3.0 took 4 seconds with a transfer speed of about 130MB/second. Seagate to Acer on USB 2.0 took 12 seconds with a transfer speed of about 30MB/second. The transfer was "smooth" in both cases. Acer to Seagate on USB 3.0 took 8 seconds with a transfer speed of about 90MB/second. The progress bar indicated that the vast majority of the file went in 6 sec but then the progress bar hesitated and the final tiny bit took a further 2 seconds. Acer to Seagate on USB 2.0 took 18 seconds with a transfer speed of about 70MB/second. The progress bar indicated that the vast majority of the file went in 8 sec but then the progress bar hesitated and the final tiny bit took a further 10 seconds. Just out of curiosity I tried transferring files on my old USB 2.0 only Dell 420 XPS desktop and transferring the single video file from the Dell to the Seagate took about 20 seconds with the same kind of hesitation at the end. However transferring the file from the Seagate to the Dell went in about 12 seconds with no hesitation at the end. The 25GB mixed folder went from the Dell to the Seagate in 19 minutes, 24MB/sec, and from the Seagate to the Dell in 16 minutes. For users who want the Facebook and back up options or if you are pushed for time and want to transfer large file then this Seagate should be just what you need.

5|As the tutorial videos are keen to mention, Seagate have been the leader in Hard Drive technology for over 30 years. This latest release has 2 major marketing points - its size, and its new Seagate Dashboard technology. At first, I was alittle dismayed when opening the box to find zero instructions, but generally with hard drives it's a simple case of plug in and go. In a clever, and obvious way to cut down on unnecessary packaging, companies like Seagate are becoming more innovative in delivering their insructional content. Seagate have been providing soft copy guides within their hardware, as well as links to online instructions for some time now. This time, included on the hard drive are 4 tutorial videos - an introduction to the product, protection (PEACE OF MIND!), saving social media files, and sharing social media files. Those last 3 videos discuss how to use the Seagate Dashboard technology, which is quite clever and simple to use once you have completed the download. It should be stressed that you don't need to use this software in order to use the product, but that if buying this particualr product rather than another, that would be the intention. The videos are typical grating American nonsene, all glossy, smiley, and vapid presentations by your new best friend Janelle (Hi! I'm Janelle!). They are informative, and by and large contain all the information you need, but you'll likely delete after one (or half) viewing. They come in a series of languages, from English and French, to Korean, Chinese, and beyond. The first thing I did naturally, was transfer a few large files to and from the Hard Drive via the USB 3.0 cable, which worked perfectly fine - fast, easy, as it should be. The Dashboard functionality works well for those who don't want the hassle of uploading to or from social media sites - there is the option to register for free online cloud storage for a year, but I didn't go for this in case they keep pestering me once the year is up. Size wise it is again remarkably small for those of us who remember when you had to keep all your music and movies in honest-to-God boxes, shelves, and cupboards. It is considerably lighter than the last Seagate I got(the 1TB portable built in Wifi device, and it retains the sleek, modern feel with a simple finish, 1 logo, 1 light. It's a little pricey at the moment for a hard drive with around 500Gb storage, but if you want something slim line or crave that social networking ease, then this is a strong contender, especially when, as Janelle reminds us (Hi! I'm Janelle!) that Seagate have been the leader in Hard Drive technology for over 30 years. Did I say that already? PEACE OF MIND!

Unclear what made the reader head/arm fail after a few hours use each time, but the individual drive I had was clearly no use as a back-up. The drive was returned to Amazon within the standard 30 day period, with a prompt and full refund with no difficulties. Although a minor hassle, in some ways glad mine was faulty straight out of the box rather than losing everything a few weeks/months down the line. The identical drive bought by my girlfriend at the same time I bought mine still seems to working fine. Whether I was just unlucky and had a one-in-10,000 faulty drive, or whether there is an underlying weakness to this model isn't yet clear, but I'll be sticking clear of it and looking for something else.

5|For me, this is a perfect upgrade from my old Toshiba portable drive which had too many annoying habits to mention. The first impression is that of a solidly built device; a sturdy metal case and it comes with a (very) short USB3 cable. No power supply is needed as this is USB powered. I connected this up using the supplied cable but others may find the cable too short. Note that if you want USB3 speeds, only a USB3 cable will do; you can’t use a USB2 cable & expect the highest speeds. Even though the USB1/2 cables will fit into this device, the USB 3 cable will not fit into a USB2 device. Using this HD with a USB2 connection on my PC, I got a respectable 20bps transfer rate. This isn’t as good as, say, my Corsair USB3 memory stick which attains 25mbps but is acceptable. With a USB3 connection, the real-world transfer speed went up to over 100mbps! There’s no software needed to use the HD but Seagate’s backup software is included on the drive. I’ve not tried this yet but will update my review once I have. Overall this is a worthy upgrade from my older portable drive. At a current RRP of around £60, this is good value, given the transfer speeds and build quality.

1|The pictures are wrong. They are not of the STDR1000200. They are of the STBU1000200. The STBU is the old Backup Plus, the STDR is the new and bad one.(The Expansion is STBX) This external HDD does not follow the SATA standard and does not use a SATA connector internally. This is no longer a USM drive and you can no longer use the Seagate USM Thunderbolt adapter and the Seagate USM Firewire adapter. Internally this is no longer a normal SATA 2.5" drive. The USB adapter is integrated into the board of the HDD. If you take it out you can no longer put this inside a laptop or in a caddy because there is no SATA connector. BUT this is not a native USB drive(no speed advantage), it still uses a USB-SATA bridge but it is integrated on the board of the HDD. This is just a cost cutting measure that results in nonstandard products. It is a stupid trend started by Western Digital(all of their current external portable drives do NOT follow the SATA standard). Buy the old USM compatible Seagate Backup Plus (STBU1000200) or the Seagate Expansion (STBX1000200) instead.

1|The photo showing the drive 'standing up' on its shorter edge is misleading. Some Seagate drives do stand up that way, but not this one. It has a much bigger footprint - takes up a lot more space. More importantly, this drive is incompatibe with file writing software, which means its ok as a backup storage drive if you simply want to copy files on to it and nothing else, but it won't allow software such as DVD Shrink to write files to it and if you create the files using another drive and then copy them over, some software and some other devices (e.g. DVD Player, TV) will not be able to read them. Be warned... most external Seagate drives have the same problems. There is one satisfactory Seagate external drive that I can vouch for: it's branded Seagate 2TB GoFlex Desk - comes in a blue and black retail box with an (accurate) illustration of the drive working in the 'standing up' position. But the Seagate 'BackUp Plus' range of drives and the Seagate 'Expansion' range of drives all have the same problems. Good luck finding a Seagate 'GoFlex Desk' by the way. Nobody seems to have them in stock. In case you're wondering what the crucial difference might be that makes the GoFlex so satisfactory and all Seagate's other drives so very UNsatisfactory... I don't know. And Seagate tech support - which is not the best - either can't say or won't say or they don't know. After trying three Seagate drives (one 3TB, two 2TB) recently and getting nowhere, I've given up and bought a 2TB from Western Digital instead. (WD 'Elements'). Immediately clear to see that it's a much better build quality and, yes, it works perfectly in all respectas - and does it straight out of the box. Here it is: http://amzn.to/1s7VnmZ

5|I use this 1TB drive more as a mobile media centre (plugging it in to various devices wherever I go) than as a back-up drive. However, considering the it has half the capacity of my 2TB desktop, I could easilu use it as a backup. Luckily I have a WD 4TB drive for that... so much space!!! The Seagate is very slim, small and pocketable. It runs using a non-standard usb cable so make sure you look after that cable - which could have been longer, it's only about 6 inches long... - but doesn't require any external power on most modern devices. I can easily run it off my PS3 or bluray player. However, I had high hopes that it would work with my Raspberry Pi, but I think the power demnands are simply too high as it just blinked at me and did nothing. There is in-built software to enable you to set-up regular back-ups, which is very handy if that's what you want to use it for. Personally, it's my very own almost-bottomless media device. I just wish my main PC had USB 3.0 ports, so I could make the most of the increased speeds. Having said that, the write and read speeds are very good over USB 2.0 - a 1080p movie will start on my bluray player within 20 secs of hitting play. Not bad at all. Seagate are a well-known brand and recognised for their quality. The fact that my old Seagate drive failed cos the USB input collapsed inside is prob my own fault for mistreating it (I was always dropping the damn slippery thing). This drive has a pleasing matte finish, simple LED to let you know its working, and is silent in operation. Simply, it's excellent!

5|Firstly let me say, i didn't buy this from amazon as I had vouchers for argos i got it there! I now have two of these guys (one grey one blue) the grey one which i have had for almost a year now, which I use for time machine backups. really works well with this no problems so far. I like the little light that lights up on the top left through an etch in the metal cover. one thing I don't like with macs is they don't show disk activity without a download. This is a nice touch I bought the second one because I was looking for a 2gb internal laptop drive, (Do this at your own risk) this item includes the samsung spinpoint M9T, I have seen many youtube videos that show people opening this device, they seem to have had some trouble getting this open using credit cards picks etc, I seem to have been lucky in that i got the metal cover straight off using only my fingernails first time. (i don't really have much in the way of fingernails btw) its then just a case of gently easing the drive out of the plastic bottom, with a screwdriver and then taking off the metallic foil and gently coaxing off the usb3 adaptor, then its a case of putting in the drive to whichever computer as normal. This saves a good deal of money. The drive has the standard sata connectors and the usb 3 adaptor is not soldered to the drive. Before I dismantled the drive i first ran blackmagic disk speed test, This drive runs about 120mbs per second read and write on usb3 so pretty much will not be any faster using usb 2 or 3. I will when I put the disk into my macbook test to see if there is any difference in speed with the drive as a secondary drive in the pc and then update this post. The disk comes formatted as ntfs which can be read by both mac and pc, It comes with backup software (on the drive itself) which allows backup of normal content, social media, and cloud based content. ( personally i stopped using it as its not really useful on mac due to time machine) but it is a simple and quick install. Contents The drive universal Usb 3 cable ( makes it easy to get another one if one breaks) instructions. Pros slim drive (9mm drive) case is attractive you really get 2TB space ( really impressed this is actually 2TB formatted under NTFS most drives lie about the physical space and you end up with a lot less) Good price much cheaper than the samsung M9T on its on. usb 2 and 3 Reliable Portable Cons, Not really the fastest drive (good for backups though) usb 2 and 3 obtain same speed as drive cannot reach usb2 or 3 speeds All in all a great drive. go get one
4|With music, films and books being delivered digitally more often, hard drive manufacturers must be rubbing their hands with glee. I have several external portable drives that I use for backing up my Windows PC, Mac laptop, photos and music but most are USB 2.0 so I've been adding some faster USB 3.0 drives lately. The Seagate drives are small and lightweight and have decent capacities. Backing up my photo library I was able to get around 40MB per second when copying from my NAS server over a gigabit ethernet connection to my PC and then USB 3.0 to the Seagate drive. That's not too bad at all. It seems with any external drive people's experience will vary, however I've not had any problems with any of mine. It's worth remembering though that the internal mechanism is fairly fragile so bouncing around in a rucksack is not a great idea, nor bringing it from the cold into a warm environment. If doing the latter allow it to acclimatise before attempting to use it.

5|I own other Seagate drives and have found that Seagate offers good, reliable storage. Packing 500gb of storage in a very slim, sophisticated shell, this little beauty doesn't disappoint. The drive is very slim and extremely light so it is hard to believe that you are holding 500gb of storage in your hand. I still have my first portable drive which is 120gb and it is at least 4 times as chunky as this. My first 500gb external hard drive still sits on my desk and it looks like a brick compared to this little specimen of minimalist perfection. Finished in a brushed metal effect, it looks lovely and should withstand the occasional scratch or scuff that a shiny, polished finish would show too easily. It also means that it won't show all those nasty finger smudges that would inevitably show up on a polished surface. Complete with USB 3.0 connectivity out of the box, it will download and backup your data quickly and effortlessly and of course it is backwards compatible. The Seagate Slim also utilises the Seagate Dashboard, which although I initially thought it was a bit superfluous as I managed just as well dragging and dropping to transfer files, does have the added benefit of a protect function which can be set to automatically backup data. Backup can also be linked to social networking - a feature of modern tech which seems to be taking over our lives and the share feature allows for uploading multiple files easily and quickly. Another bonus for those who may move between different platforms is that the Seagate Slim can be used interchangeably between Mac and PC without the need to reformat. This feature does not apply to me but is a nice addition and shows Seagate is thinking about its customer base and trying to make life as easy for consumers as possible. I am very pleased with my Seagate Slim and will make good use of its portable 500gb. My poor 120gb drive was full long ago and I was in dire need of a replacement. I am obsessive about backing up and saving multiple copies of my data and this little beauty should make that part of my life a lot easier.
